urn:contentItem:5WCM-YGC1-F0C5-X35B-00000-00No to a breakup, no to everything: Google shoots down shareholder proposals2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:30ZLexisNexisNo to a breakup, no to everything: Google shoots down shareholder proposalsLevi Sumagaysay

From concerns over governance, content moderation and sexual harassment in the workplace, the number of investor resolutions -- and their inevitable failure -- highlights Google's size, reach and power.

More than a dozen shareholder proposals failed as expected at Googles annual meeting Wednesday, but they raised important questions about the massive company, which has had its share of scandals and controversy over the past year or so.

From ethical questions raised by Google products and contracts to the companys handling of sexual harassment and treatment of contract workers, Google CEO Sundar Pichai, Chairman John Hennessy and other executives got an earful from disgruntled investors, advocacy groups and employees at the meeting in Sunnyvale while protesters marched outside.

Among the defeated proposals was one that sought a breakup of the company. The presenter of the proposal, a representative of Students for a Free Tibet, urged the company to take steps now rather than waiting for antitrust regulators to act. As the internet giant faces possible U.S. antitrust inquiries and calls to break it up, she said the company has grown to a complexity that is unmanageable.

Another proposal that failed urged the company to study and share an assessment of the human rights implications of Project Dragonfly, Googles reported plan to once again operate a search engine in China.

As weve said, we have no plans to open a search engine in China, said Kent Walker, senior vice president for global affairs and chief legal officer for Google, during the meetings Q&A session. CEO Sundar Pichai said in a New York Times interview in November, after employees protested and quit over the issue, It's not even clear to me that search in China is the product we need to do today.

There were more than a few mentions of recent employee protests and actions during the meeting, including one in November when thousands of workers walked off the job in response to a report of huge payouts to executives accused of sexual misconduct and harassment. A proposal for a clawback policy, in which an executive would be forced to pay the company back in case of misconduct, did not pass, either.

After the proposal to install a non-executive employee representative on the board of directors failed, a Google employee said during the Q&A: Whats really stuck out to me recently is this shift when we're challenged, she said. I've seen executives feign powerlessness as if we're not a company the size of some countries. We're told we can't take dramatic action. When we respond this way it's disingenuous. We're choosing to use our power to solve the wrong problems, and we can do better.

Yolanda Chavez, who spoke at the meeting as a representative of Silicon Valley Rising, expressed concerns about Googles plan for a giant campus in San Jose.

Yesterday's announcement (a $1 billion pledge by the company to help with Bay Area housing) was a positive sign that Google is listening to the community, she said through a translator. But Chavez noted that the 5,000 in affordable-housing units Pichai mentioned in a blog post as part of the plan are needed in San Jose alone, according to a study she cited. What's your plan to mitigate Google's impact on San Jose?

Chief Financial Officer Ruth Porat answered that our announcement really underscores our commitment to Bay Area, and pointed to other initiatives by the company, including its philanthropic arm Google.org, which she said is working on housing, and in trying to teach digital skills.

One shareholder complained that Alphabet CEO Larry Page wasnt present. Page and Google co-founder Sergey Brin are seldom seen at public company events.

Maybe one year he's sick, the shareholder said. But year after year, there's no CEO here.

Because of the companys multi-class stock structure, Page and Brin together have 51 percent of voting shares, a reason shareholder resolutions fail year after year.

But theyre a way to keep putting pressure on Google, which needs it, said Don Heider, executive director of the Markkula Center for Applied Ethics at Santa Clara University.

There are pockets of Google working on ethics, but not an overarching commitment that's taking place, Heider said.

Heider said big tech companies including Google have asked ethicists to talk to them in the past year as theyve increasingly come under fire, and one member of the center is working half-time with the company to try to help build ethics into the companys products and designs.

urn:contentItem:5XT5-H7P1-DYX2-02HD-00000-00Not only a Space Force, but now maybe a Cyber Force2019-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:30ZLexisNexisNot only a Space Force, but now maybe a Cyber Force

Good morning. This is your CQ Cyber newsletter for Friday Dec. 20, 2019. We'll have one more newsletter on Dec. 24, and then we'll take a break until Tuesday, Jan. 7. Happy Holidays to you all.

TOPLINES

1. The Cyber Force awakens: Congress is using the latest defense authorization bill to ask the Pentagon if it should create a new branch of the armed forces dedicated to cybersecurity.

2. Tracking faces in public housing: House and Senate Democrats want the Department of Housing and Urban Development to review use of facial recognition in federally subsidized housing.

3. How Libra upended 2019: The nascent fintech industry had hoped Congress would pass bills in its favor this year. Then came Facebook's Libra, bringing with it increased scrutiny and concern.

4. Americans unplugged: The number of households without internet access is shrinking, albeit slowly. But new census data shows significant gaps still exist in both rural and urban areas.

5. Facebook friendly: Lawmakers praised Facebook for announcing it would crack down on any misinformation on its platform relating to the 2020 U.S. Census

FULL BRIEFING

1. Congress asks Pentagon if U.S. needs a cybersecurity branch of armed forces

Lawmakers are using the fiscal 2020 defense authorization bill to ask the Pentagon to study whether a separate uniformed service dedicated to cybersecurity should be created, my colleague Gopal Ratnam writes.

President Donald Trump is scheduled to sign the NDAA bill Friday night at Andrews Air Force Base.

The National Defense Authorization Act (S 1970) asks the Defense Department to assess "the potential costs, benefits, and value, if any, of establishing a cyber force as a separate uniformed service."

If it comes to pass, a future cyber force would become the seventh branch of the U.S. armed forces, alongside the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Coast Guard, and a new Space Force currently taking shape.

The congressional directive comes as lawmakers are increasingly worried that the overwhelming U.S. strength in conventional and nuclear forces is unlikely to deter future adversaries that are likely to resort to cyberattacks on U.S. military and civilian infrastructure to undermine American strength.

Lawmakers also included a variety of other cybersecurity related provisions in the defense policy bill.

One of the measures tightens the accountability screws on the Pentagon by asking the department to submit written reports for why major U.S. weapons systems have not undergone a cyber vulnerability assessment.

In the 2016 Pentagon policy bill (PL 114-92) lawmakers had asked the department to complete "an evaluation of the cyber vulnerabilities of each major weapon system" by Dec. 31, 2019. It's unclear if the Pentagon completed the assessment either in part or in full.

In this year's bill, lawmakers said if the Defense secretary "determines that the Department will not complete an evaluation of the cyber vulnerabilities of each major weapon system" then the secretary must provide congressional committees a "justification for the inability to complete" such an assessment.

Once an assessment is complete, lawmakers want to see what cyber weaknesses were identified in each weapon, steps to mitigate those, and a deadline by which the fixes would be applied.

The U.S. Government Accountability Office in a report last year said that despite the Pentagon's plans to spend as much as $1.66 trillion to develop major weapons, adversaries could render them useless by attacking the underlying computers.

"Automation and connectivity are fundamental enablers of DOD's modern military capabilities," the GAO said. "However, they make weapon systems more vulnerable to cyberattacks. Although GAO and others have warned of cyber risks for decades, until recently, DOD did not prioritize weapon systems cybersecurity. Finally, DOD is still determining how best to address weapon systems cybersecurity."

Read Gopal's full report on cybersecurity provisions in this year's NDAA here.

2. Facial recognition use in public housing questioned by lawmakers

A group of House and Senate Democrats are asking Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson to provide information on the use of facial recognition technology in public housing.

In a letter to Carson on Thursday, the Democrats, led by Sens. Ron Wyden of Oregon, expressed concern that use of the technology in federally subsidized housing could lead to unwarranted government surveillance and civil liberties concerns.

The Democrats also said that because facial recognition algorithms have been shown to be inaccurate when dealing with vulnerable communities, use of facial recognition could have unintended consequences "such as the over-criminalization of people of color and transgender individuals."

"When public housing and federally assisted property owners install facial recognition security camera systems, they could be used to enable invasive, unnecessary and harmful government surveillance of their residents," the Democrats wrote. "Those who cannot afford more do not deserve less in basic privacy and protections. They should not have to compromise their civil rights and liberties nor accept the condition of indiscriminate, sweeping government surveillance to find an affordable place to live."

Wyden was joined by Sens. Cory Booker of New Jersey, Sherrod Brown of Ohio, Kamala Harris of California, and Edward J Markey of Massachusetts. House members co-signing the letter included Reps. Yvette D. Clarke of New York, Ayanna S. Pressley of Massachusetts and Rashida Tlaib of Michigan.

Booker has introduced legislation (S 2689) that would ban the use of facial recognition technology in public housing. Clarke, Pressley and Tlaib have introduced a companion bill (HR 4008) in the House.

The lawmakers asked Carson for a full list of housing units that have used facial recognition technology in the past five years and information on the use of federal dollars to purchase facial recognition technology for housing. They asked for a response by Jan. 24.

Read the full letter from Wyden and his colleagues here.

3. Rules, privacy issues loom for fintech industry in 2020

The nascent financial technology industry started the year faintly optimistic that the 116th Congress would pass bills in its favor. But as 2019 comes to an end without legislation, the industry isn't even expecting action in 2020.

And for that, they're feeling relieved, not disappointed, my colleague Jim Saksa writes.

Facebook Inc.'s midyear announcement that it planned to launch a cryptocurrency, Libra, upended the industry's focus, tilting the legislative strategy from pressing hard for beneficial bills to staying clear of measures aimed at checking the social media giant's ambitions to transform commerce.

Now, with the possible exception of a data privacy bill and a smattering of smaller measures, congressional observers in the fintech world expect 2020 will maintain the statutory status quo.

"Towards the end of the year, we started to see a couple different proposals circulated in the House that would go after Libra," said Kristin Smith of the Blockchain Association, an industry trade group.

But those proposals, such as a bill from Rep. Sylvia R. Garcia, D-Texas, that would have regulated managed stable coins like Libra as securities, were narrowly tailored, Smith said, calling it a positive sign.

"The fact that this is looking at a subset of crypto known as managed stable coins is pretty remarkable," she said, noting the bill could have targeted all cryptocurrencies. "It's a very nuanced approach and answering a very targeted question."

That's a far cry from the spring, when the Blockchain Association hoped a bill that would have prevented digital tokens from being labeled as securities would make it to a House Financial Services Committee markup at the least.

Smith said she expects to see more measures aimed at discouraging Silicon Valley from moving onto Wall Street's turf than those doing the opposite. She said the House Financial Services Committee could still mark up Garcia's bill next year along with similar proposals with names like the "Keep Big Tech Out of Financial Services Act."

The fintech world "dodged a bullet" with that bill, said Jonah Crane, a former Treasury Department staffer and aide to Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, who now advises fintech firms. "I don't see high odds that those kind of bills will go anywhere, but they are the kind of bills that, if they start to get momentum, could be hard to stop because of the general antipathy towards Big Tech these days."

Read Jim's full report on the 2020 fintech forecast here.

4. Census data shows much of country still lacks internet access

Rural areas and inner cities share a common thread, according to census data released Thursday: a lack of access to the internet, a gap that has closed slowly over the years, my colleague Michael Macagnone writes.

Nationally, more than 80 percent of households reported having access to broadband internet of some kind in 2018, according to the data released Thursday. That's up from about 74 percent who had it five years earlier. However, inner cities and rural areas have a large number of the households without a wired or mobile internet subscription of any kind, despite years of federal programs building out capacity in those regions.

The percentage of households without internet access goes up considerably in rural areas. More than half the households in rural Echols County, Ga., don't have an internet subscription, for instance.

Republican Rep. Earl L. "Buddy" Carter said the challenges for his district, which includes Echols, are not substantially different from other rural areas. He said internet access came up at an agriculture convention in his district earlier this year, but that expanding access also will be critical in helping other businesses thrive.

"Precision agriculture just begs for this, this type of service, so it is going to be really important, there's no question about that," Carter said.

On the other end of the spectrum is Michigan's densely populated Wayne County, which includes Detroit.

More than 180,000 Wayne County households -- just more than a quarter of all the homes -- have no internet subscription of any kind, according to census data. Despite having less than 2 million people, the county ranks among the top 10 nationwide for households without internet access.

The data released Thursday showed that homes that lack internet access also tend to have lower incomes. For instance, more than half the Wayne County households that earned less than $20,000 a year did not have an internet subscription.

A report from Pew Research released in May found that rural areas lagged behind their suburban and urban counterparts in getting an internet connection at home. About 63 percent of the Pew respondents in rural areas said they had internet at home, compared to 75 percent of urban respondents and 79 percent of suburban ones.

Access to the internet can help businesses find customers, customers find products, and increase communications between and within businesses. A 2016 Council of Economic Advisers report found that internet access spurs more than $30 billion in economic activity, as well as access to services like telemedicine and online education.

Read Michael's full report on the new census data here.

5. Facebook will take down misleading information on U.S. Census

The same day Congress prepared to send the White House a sweeping spending package that includes $7.6 billion for the Census Bureau, Facebook announced it would remove incorrect or misleading census information from its platform next year.

The social media giant's announcement follows steps by Google and the Census Bureau itself to keep online outreach efforts on track for the 2020 count.

Members of Congress pushing for more active involvement from social media companies, including Sen. Brian Schatz, D-Hawaii, took a "trust but verify" approach to Facebook's move on Thursday.

"I have been a real critic of these internet platforms, and let me take this opportunity to say that in this instance they appear to be doing the right thing," Schatz said.

Facebook joined several other internet companies by announcing it would remove information from its platform that misrepresents the census or the census process, even if posted by a politician. The company also said it would work with the Census Bureau and local officials to help track any distortion about the census online.

Next month, the agency will start its count, beginning with residents of rural Alaska. It also will kick off a $500 million advertising campaign before efforts to count more than 300 million American residents start in the spring. The agency has invested more than $5 billion in information technology and computer upgrades for a series of innovations, including the nation's first primarily online census count.

Part of those funds will go toward online efforts to promote the census process. The agency announced on Tuesday that its "Trust & Safety" team also will act as a clearinghouse for efforts to stop the online spread of misinformation.

Rep. Jamie Raskin, the Maryland Democrat who heads the House Oversight and Reform Committee panel that oversees the census, praised the Facebook announcement as "good news" and commended the Census Bureau's efforts.

"The government has a responsibility to defend our elections and defend a civic process like the census, so that's good news," Raskin said.

Read Michael Macagnone's full report on Facebook and the Census here.

Bitcoin Billionaires says, Yes2019-05-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:31ZLexisNexisDatebookPg. E1Notorious Winklevoss twins cast in new lightWere the Winklevoss twins misunderstood? Bitcoin Billionaires says, Yes By Brandon Yu

David Fincher's 2010 film, "The Social Network," chronicled the rise of Facebook from Harvard dorm rooms to a revolutionary multibillion-user social network. It also etched a particular impression of a set of twins named Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss.

The two were remembered flatly as the chiseled, privileged jocks who sued Mark Zuckerberg for stealing the idea behind Facebook. In the years since, things have changed, with twists of irony. Zuckerberg has become the face of the pitfalls and evils of big tech, and the twins are now lauded as the prescient poster boy entrepreneurs behind the tech breakthrough known as cryptocurrency.

The Winklevoss brothers are cast in this fresh light in "Bitcoin Billionaires" the new book from Ben Mezrich, the author of "The Accidental Billionaires," which "The Social Network" was based on. Mezrich spoke with The Chronicle about his new book, scheduled for release Tuesday, May 21, and how it serves as both a corrective origin story of the Winklevoss twins and a thrilling primer on the future of currency.

Q: What led you back to the Winklevoss twins for this book?

A: For the past couple years, people have been calling me and emailing me saying, you should write about bitcoin, because I write about that sort of thing. But it's never interested me. . But I read the New York Times headline that the Winklevii twins were the "Bitcoin Billionaires." It blew my mind. Because these were the same guys who were the bad guys in "The Social Network," and suddenly they were standing sort of at the beginning of another revolution.

Q: Part of the perception of them as 'bad guys' comes from your book "The Accidental Billionaires." But in this new book, you re-evaluate them. What was initially wrong about your understanding of the twins?

A: When I wrote "The Accidental Billionaires," the twins were one of my main sources. I had gotten to know them pretty well. But I had judged them. They were easy to judge. ... But at the same time, there was this kind of really incredible streak of 1950s kind of morality that I think their characters always had. They really believe in this sort of "Men of Harvard" and this idea of right and wrong, and this idea of - you get knocked down and you get back up. They really felt that Mark Zuckerberg screwed them. It wasn't about money. It was about being betrayed. And I think there's something very respectable about that, even in the initial telling of the story.

I really do think that as much as we got Mark Zuckerberg right in the original telling, we got the Winklevii twins wrong. They are those guys. They are the mirror twins rowing together. They are the big men on campus, and they are the guys who wore suits to meet with Larry Summers. But at the same time, they speak multiple languages and they studied Latin. They can computer code, and they understand economics. They weren't part of these two revolutions by accident.

Q: Zuckerberg's own public standing has shifted dramatically in his relationship to issues of privacy and the choices he's made with Facebook. What are your thoughts on this narrative shift?

A: I do think this is who he's been all along. I really think from the very beginning, he set out to dominate and change the social order. He believed from the very beginning that the walls we build of privacy are bad. And that the more we share and the more our data is out there, the better the world is.

Q: Chris Hughes, a co-founder of Facebook, recently wrote an opinion piece that called for breaking up the "monopoly" that is Facebook. What was your reaction?

A: The idea of breaking up Facebook - I don't even know what that really means. Cut out Instagram so we all either join Facebook or Instagram? That doesn't make any difference. And I don't know how breaking it up really changes anything. The problem with these technologies is they need to dominate. They have to be a monopoly for them to work. If everyone's not on Facebook, then Facebook is kind of useless, right? I think what Chris Hughes is really trying to say is there shouldn't be a Facebook anymore. And I don't know if that's the answer either.

Q: What do you see as an answer?

A: I think a simple fix to Facebook is it becomes a subscription, that you pay a certain fee to be on Facebook that gets rid of the whole idea of selling data. You can wall your privacy as much as you want because they're not making any money off of it. I think that's one possibility - a subscription method. There's a couple of other possibilities.

The idea of regulation - everyone hates regulation, but at the same time, when you have something so dominant in our lives, so incredibly powerful, there has to be some oversight. It can't just be Mark Zuckerberg sitting in a room, saying I'm going to decide who gets to say what.

Q: You write in the prologue that cryptocurrency is "a fundamental paradigm shift, and it will eventually change everything." How do you see the future of cryptocurrency?

A: I know that's somewhat controversial. I do think there are going to be people on either side of that. Listen, 100 years from now, we are not going to be paying for things with cut-down trees in an animal-hide wallet. We're not going to be bartering with cash. Cash is not going to exist in the future. I really don't see that happening.

I can't imagine 100 years from now, with our automatic cars and with our phones that pay for everything, there's going to be any need or want for cash. The future is crypto. It's some sort of electronic currency that is instantly transferable, that doesn't have any particular government making decisions over it and that isn't run by a single bank. As long as you've got stable governments, cash makes sense. But as soon as your country doesn't do so well, your cash becomes very scary.

In Cyprus, literally overnight they just took everyone's deposits, took a percentage of everyone's money. Up to 50% of your money just vanished the next day. And you think, well, it can't ever happen in America. No, it can't right now happen in America. But one day, if things go to s-, certainly it could.

Q: Two of your books have become films "21" and "The Social Network". Are there similar plans here as well?

A: It's going to be a big movie. I don't have any specifics to tell you, other than Columbia Pictures, which did "The Social Network," would be distributing it. I would love to see Armie Hammer play the twins again, but it's too early to tell at this point. But, yes, it is going to be a movie.

Bitcoin Billionaires: A True Story of Genius, Betrayal, and Redemption

By Ben Mezrich

Flatiron Books

288 pages; $27.99

Tyler left and Cameron Winklevoss, known for their legal battles over Facebook are the focus of Bitcoin Billionaires.

Ben Mezrich recasts the Winklevoss twins as the good guys in Bitcoin Billionaires.

Ben Mezrich is the author of The Accidental Billionaires, which the movie The Social Network was based on. His latest book is Bitcoin Billionaires.

C1NET WORTHNo Trump bump for stock of tech firmsNo Trump bump for tech stocks, which tumble for second dayBy Kathleen Pender

The Dow Jones industrial average got a second Trump bump Thursday, rising 218 points, or 1.17 percent, to an all-time high of 18,807.88. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 0.8 percent, dragged down by a broad-based sell-off in tech stocks.

The big tech names got hit hard: Alphabet and Apple lost 2.9 and 2.8 percent, respectively; Microsoft was down 2.4 percent; Facebook fell 1.9 percent; Twitter dropped almost 4 percent; Netflix lost 5.5 percent; and Amazon.com fell 3.8 percent.

In the two days since Donald Trump was elected president, the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 index has fallen 1.2 percent while the Dow has gained 2.6 percent.

So what's the trouble with tech? The simple answer is sector rotation. The theory is that under a Trump administration, interest rates will rise, regulations will ease and infrastructure spending will grow. Investors are moving money into industries that would do best under that scenario - especially financials, industrials and materials - and out of sectors that will benefit less, namely technology and real estate.

Another concern is that Trump's trade and immigration policies could hurt tech. "He certainly has talked about cracking down on immigration. The tech sector is one that relies most heavily on H-1B visas," said Dave Nadig, director of exchange-traded funds with FactSet.

Tech is also highly dependent on the global supply chain. If a trade disagreement caused a disruption to the chain, "tech more than other industries would be affected," said Russ Koesterich, head of asset allocation for BlackRock's Global Allocation Fund.

Another fear is that Trump could overturn or weaken the Federal Communication Commission's net neutrality policy, which essentially says that Internet service providers cable and phone companies should not favor certain websites and apps over others.

"The Obama administration was pro-net neutrality with an FCC that was increasing regulation around the cable companies," said Jason Helfstein, an analyst with Oppenheimer.

Although it wasn't a big issue for Trump during the campaign, net neutrality could come under attack as part of his "broad theme of deregulation," Helfstein said.

For tech, taxes are a mixed bag. Trump has proposed chopping the top corporate tax rate to 15 percent from 35 percent. But many big tech companies already have low effective tax rates. "There are sectors other than tech that would benefit more" from a tax cut, Koesterich said.

Today, U.S. companies don't have to pay U.S. tax on foreign profits until they bring them back to the United States. Many tech companies have large unrepatriated earnings sitting offshore. Trump has proposed letting U.S. companies bring home foreign profits at a rate of 10 percent, payable over 10 years. That "could help large-cap tech if they could bring it back at a discounted rate," said Aaron Kessler, an analyst with Raymond James & Associates

However, Trump has also said he would tax future profits of foreign subsidiaries of U.S. companies each year as the profits are earned.

Finally, an increase in long-term interest rates - like we've seen in the past two days - generally helps banks, but hurts tech and other growth companies that are valued more on their future profits than current ones, Nadig said.

urn:contentItem:5S30-FTX1-JD3N-51D1-00000-00No trust: congress needs to step in2018-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:31ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 8No trust: congress needs to step inCAMERON STEWART, COMMENT

The big question which Mark Zuckerberg did not answer yesterday is whether the world should believe his latest apology and trust him to right Facebook's wrongs.

For much of Facebook's 14-year existence, the 33-year-old founder of the social network has made a habit of apologising for shortcomings in his platform. "Don't worry, we will do better and all will be fixed," he has promised on numerous occasions since Facebook was launched in 2004.

As commerce committee chairman John Thune put it yesterday: "After more than a decade of promises to do better, how is today's apology different?" In short, Zuckerberg's testimony to the US congress means nothing without concrete action and results.

Faced with incontrovertible evidence that the social network has been cavalier with the privacy and data of its two billion-plus users, and blind to the potential of bad actors to exploit it, Zuckerberg had no choice but fall to his knees in front of Capitol Hill.

His apology was well delivered and appropriately contrite. The well-coached chief executive buried his propensity for arrogance and answered patiently as he was questioned in an often incompetent manner by aged senators who sounded as if they barely understood the internet, much less the intricacies of Facebook.

As a result, few of them were able to properly tackle Zuckerberg over the central mysteries of exactly how his algorithms work to deliver targeted advertising to users. Or precisely what protections there are to safeguard personal privacy. As Zuckerberg progressively realised this, his nervous demeanour vanished and he became more relaxed and assertive, even cracking jokes. The question for the senators is whether they believe his repeated promised to implement a raft of changes that will better protect the content, privacy and security of the social network.

It is a leap of faith to do so given Zuckerberg's track record of being reactive rather than proactive to the challenge of safeguarding Facebook from bad actors. But the alternative for congress is also difficult - a new regulatory regime for Facebook and other tech giants which congress has traditionally shied away from.

However, the EU has shown the courage the US has lacked by taking on the tech giants with sweeping privacy laws which take effect from next month.The scandals that have enveloped Facebook prove that Washington can no longer rely on big tech to self-regulate in this new era of social media. It's time for congress to step in and do what is needed to ensure that tech giants like Facebook are held accountable rather than becoming the robber barons of the internet era.

urn:contentItem:60T3-26N1-JCMN-Y0J9-00000-00No, Twitter Should Not Take Down The McConnell Parody2020-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:30ZLexisNexisNo, Twitter Should Not Take Down The McConnell Parodyjonathanturley

Sep 09, 2020( JonathanTurley.org: http://jonathanturley.org Delivered by Newstex) https://i1.wp.com/jonathanturley.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/moscowmitch-560.jpg?ssl=1For years, I have criticized those who have called for increased censorship on the Internet[1], including regulation of political speech by companies like Facebook and Twitter. There is a legitimate debate over the continued use of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act by these companies when they are engaged in such censorship (and alleged viewpoint bias). However, President Donald Trump's call for Twitter to take down a parody of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is wrong on a number of levels. It would only fuel the erosion of free speech on the Internet in curtailing political commentary.Yesterday, President Trump struck out at the picture of McConnell in a Russian military uniform:

https://imgur.com/ybHugWr The tweet says: Why does Twitter leave phony pictures like this up, but take down Republican/Conservative pictures and statements that are true? Mitch must fight back and repeal Section 230, immediately. Stop biased Big Tech before they stop you! It is a particularly curious objection from a politician who regularly parodies his political opponents with insulting names and descriptions. Parody is one of the oldest forms of political discourse. Since Hegemon of Thasos, parodia has been a literary device and an important form of political speech. Parody and satire have long been used to emphasize (and often exaggerate) political objections to our leaders. In White v. Samsung Elec. Am., Inc., 989 F.2d 1512, 1519 (9th Cir. 1993), then Chief Judge Alex Kozinski wrote in dissent that 'TheFirstAmendmentisn't just about religion or politics - it's also about protecting the free development of our national culture.Parody, humor, irreverence are all vital components of the marketplace of ideas.' The Supreme Court has repeated affirmed the importance of parody and satire as protected speech. In Campbell v. Acuff-Music, Inc., 510 U.S. 569, 579 (1994). Justice David Souter notedthat 'parody has an obvious claim to transformative value.' Even vulgar parodies have been protected like the fake advertisement featuring evangelical minister Jerry Falwell: 'At the heart of the FirstAmendment is the recognition of the fundamental importance of the free flow of ideas and opinions on matters of public interest and concern. '[T]he freedom to speak one's mind is not only an aspect of individual liberty-and thus a good unto itself-but also is essential to the common quest for truth and the vitality of society as a whole.'' Hustler Magazine, Inc. v. Falwell, 485 U.S. 46, 50-51 (1987)(quotingBose Corp. v. Consumers Union of U.S., Inc., 466 U.S. 485, 503-04 (1984)). This parody of McConnell as 'Moscow Mitch' may be unfair and insulting but it is quintessential political speech and should be protected. There is a legitimate criticism of companies like Twitter and Facebook for biased policies, but that should be part of a call for less, not more, censorship. It is not just Trump who is calling for increased censorship. I have criticized Democratic leaders who have made such limitation and regulation of free speech a central cause for their party. Hillary Clinton has demanded that political speech be regulated to avoid the 'manipulation of information' and stated that Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg 'should pay a price for what he is doing to our democracy' by refusing to take down opposition postings. In Europe, free speech rights are in a free fall, and countries such as France and Germany are imposing legal penalties designed to censor speech across the world. Joe Biden has pushed for these companies to delete criticism of mail-in voting.[2] Many of us in the free speech community have warned of the growing insatiable appetite for censorship in the West. We have been losing the fight, and free speech opponents are now capitalizing on the opportunity presented by the pandemic. Representative Adam Schiff sent a message to the heads of Google, Twitter, and YouTube demanding censorship of anything deemed 'misinformation' and 'false information.' Schiff told the companies that they needed 'to remove or limit content' and that, 'while taking down harmful misinformation is a crucial step', they also needed to educate 'those users who accessed it' by making available the true facts. All of these calls from the left and the right are efforts to control the speech of political critics and dissidents. These companies should be criticized for the bias shown in past actions, which I have previously addressed[3]. However, do not be misled by the fact that these voices are coming from opposite sides of our political debate. They are unified in the desire to curtail the most powerful forum for free speech in the history of humanity: the Internet. It is the bane of the existence of politicians around the world and they want to control it. To do that, they have to get free citizens to call for their own censorship. Many have yielded to that siren's call to the peril of free speech. That is far too high a price to pay to protect Sen. McConnell from the insults of political parody. urn:contentItem:5T9F-1JC1-F15W-H0MG-00000-00NOURIEL ROUBINI, CHARIMAN & PROFESSOR, ROUBINI MACRO ASSOCIATES NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS, CORRADO PASSERA, CEO & FOUNDER, SPAXS ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.2018-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:30ZLexisNexisNOURIEL ROUBINI, CHARIMAN & PROFESSOR, ROUBINI MACRO ASSOCIATES NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS, CORRADO PASSERA, CEO & FOUNDER, SPAXS ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.

September 18, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

NOURIEL ROUBINI, CHAIRMAN & PROFESSOR, ROUBINI MACRO ASSOCIATES NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS CORRADO PASSERA, CEO & FOUNDER, SPAXS

KEENE: And there is no one better to do that with Nouriel Roubini of New York University. Professor Roubini as acclaimed getting upfront of the crisis of 2007, I personally did that with him in Davos at one point in '05 or '06. And I'm thrilled to have Nouriel here on this important day. Let bring up from Enda Curran in Hong Kong a chart which is great because it's hard to read. I really mean that. It's hard to read this chart. Bring it up right now on radio. It is a massive disproportion of U.S. imports of China's stuff versus what they take from us. Here we are with the tariffs here, the tariffs there and China is just tiny, tiny, tiny. Professor Roubini, this is the arch-imbalance of President Trump's certitude. I heard this from Lawrence Kudlow yesterday at the economic club of New York. They speak of us as equals in trade dynamics or not, are we?

ROUBINI: We're not equal in terms of trade dynamics but has many other ways to retaliate. Of course, they've only 130 billion of imports from the U.S. while the U.S. imports from China more than 500 billion. But let's not forget that the U.S. firms, whether Apple, Gem (ph), hundreds of others, have done hundreds of billions of dollars of foreign direct investment in China. In the past, when China (inaudible) with Japan or Korea, they took action against these foreign investments, and therefore, they can retaliate and they're going to start doing it in many different ways. China can also retaliate by letting its currency weaken. Renminbi has already fallen at 8%. And then there's the nuclear option of dumping U.S. treasury, and I don't think that's likely. So the idea that there's an imbalance and China cannot retaliate, I think, is actually the wrong argument.

KEENE: Your heritage of being born in Istanbul, have studied in Milan, studied with Jeff Sax at Harvard, your international sense, your old world sense, is a study of how China will react. Jonathan Spence 101 at Yale University, how would you presume that China will react to this approach by Mr. Trump?

ROUBINI: First of all, the Chinese can be flexible. They need to do reforms and some of the reforms (inaudible) upper hand. But China and President Xi Jinping cannot lose face (ph). And what happens is that United States is starting not just a trade war with China but geopolitically wants to contain China. China is never giving up on its own Made in China 2025 program, for example. And therefore, the risk is that if you try to contain China, China is going to become actually more aggressive and less cooperative. And I think that's what's going to likely happen. They're going to retaliate in many different ways. So this is going to be counterproductive.

LACQUA: (Inaudible) from Milan, do we underestimate the dangers of a Chinese GDP that is slowing down or even does the size of shadow banking in China?

ROUBINI: Well, there has been a slowdown in China. But every time there is excessive slowdown after a tightening of monetary, fiscal and credit policy, there is an easing of monetary, credit, fiscal policy. China has not ran out of tools, yet there has been a significant correction of the stock market, 25% but the world effect is small. Yes, default rates have gone up because they are reducing leverage and align more flexibility. But that's manageable. And the currency weakening actually is occurring right now and their capital controls has not (inaudible) in 2015 and '16. And that actually helps China. If their currency goes down by 8%, the U.S. imposes tariffs on 10% is a bit of a wash in terms of their competitiveness. So China has the macroeconomic policy tools to manage its own slowdown. Of course, China, so far, has kicked the can down the road and not dealing with too much and too fast enough with the issues of overcapacity, overleverage and debt, but China is going to do it gradually. And China is going to take the long-term view. China is going to be in a long-term competition with the United States once Mao was allegedly asked what he thought of the French Revolution, he said, too early to tell. And China takes an approach a decade longer. We have midterm election, we have election ever two years, China has no elections, so they can take control on their own policies and face and threaten the U.S. over the medium and long-term. So they may win this war.

LACQUA: Right. But, Nouriel, I guess what I'm trying to get at is they do have the tools to manage a slowdown. But if they only focus domestically on what they need to do, do they let the emerging markets down and what does that mean for markets overall?

ROUBINI: Well, of course, the emerging markets are hurting right now for a number of global factors. China is one of them. The risk of trade war is one of them, either directly or through China. But then U.S. fed policies and fiscal policy, (inaudible), higher, longer and short rates, stronger dollar, and a stronger dollar means a lower dollar price of commodity. So these are the global factors that all EM are facing. But China were to react to the risk of a trade war by boosting domestic demand and maintaining its own economic growth closer to their 6.5% target, and recently, actually, they're growing faster in 6.5%, then that's going to be a backstop for emerging markets. So, of course, if China were to go to a hard landing, then that's going to hurt emerging markets, but also the U.S., Europe and the world economy. But in my view, China have still some of the policy tools to manage that economic slowdown.

KEENE: I saw Ambassador Hormats yesterday, Robert Hormats, he was an assistant of Secretary Clinton. And there is someone with a certain set of views. And I think of someone he works for, Dr. Kissinger, or Robert Kaplan, who has my book of the summer, writing about China and the Pacific Rim. All of that is a neo-realist view. What's the neo-realist response to a president who wants to put on layers of taxes called tariffs?

ROUBINI: Well, the Chinese know that, effectively, by imposing these tariffs on China, they'll increase the cost of lots of goods up to $500 billion that used by U.S. consumers. And the fact that, for example, they may introduce for September 10 and push it 25% on January 1st, is they don't want to have a (inaudible) shock for consumers during the holiday as well.

KEENE: Right. I don't mean to interrupt you but this is critical. This is Roubini 101 at Stern School New York University. Are we able to say that within all this mumbo-jumbo, a tariff is a tax on an American consumer? Is that a safe statement?

ROUBINI: Yes, it's absolutely true. Whenever you impose tariffs, you're increasing the price on imports certainly for consumer products but also for a variety of other intermediate products and the fact also the business sector. But this first (inaudible) is a tax. And by the way, it's a very regressive tax because those kinds of consumer goods that we buy from China are usually bought at Walmart and other types of firms and they're bought by lower income individuals. So not only the tax but it's an extremely regressive tax.

KEENE: And this is important, Francine, with you in Milan. I mean, the bottom line here is this is not a tax on Gucci, is it?

LACQUA: Well, let me ask Nouriel. Away from Gucci, is this a tax that could actually plunge the U.S. into a recession in the next 18 months?

ROUBINI: No. I don't think that that alone is going to plunge the U.S. into a recession, even if my prediction that a variety of other factors can push the U.S. into a recession by 2020, monetary policy, fiscal policy, the trade war, other frictions, what's happening with the rest of the world, but certainly I think that people underestimate the impact of this trade war on the economy because they say the trade impacts directly, indirectly, are too small to matter. That's not true because, first of all, you have retaliation. And as long as you have retaliation, the impact is bigger. Secondly is that tax on consumer that uses disposable income, it's going to slowdown consumption. Three, it's going to affect both business and consumer confidence. In addition, it's going to push down, emerging markets are going to hurt them, it's going to push down the price of commodity. And finally, they're going to have an effect only also on investor's confidence. If the stock market in China has gone down 20% this year under the threat of trade wars, in fact, later in the summer, the U.S. market was going down as well. So there's going to be a generalized trade war, not 50 billion, but it's going to be 500 billion and there's going to be a retaliation, there's going to be other things, there's going to be a bigger impact. And right now, this is not just a trade war. The U.S. is going to impose restriction on inward FDI (ph) into the U.S. by China to outward FDI (ph) by United States firms, they want to have all U.S. firms getting out of China, they're going to have global supply chains, technology transfer and so on and so on. So this is not just about trading goods. It's about technology, it's about IP, it's about FDI (ph), inward and outward, and you're going to roll, this is going to become de-globalized, it's going to become Volckanized, in which these frictions are going to have a negative stagflationary impact of reducing growth and increasing inflation globally. That's the danger of this trade war.

LACQUA: All right. Well, that gets us started certainly. Nouriel Roubini there of Roubini Macro Associates stays with us.

Well I'm pleased to be joined by Corrado Passera. He is SPAXS' Chief Executive Officer and Founder, former Italian Minister of Economic Development and, for almost a decade, the Chief Executive of one of Italy's biggest bank. Still with us in New York, Nouriel Roubini of Roubini Macro Associates. So thank you for sticking around, Nouriel. Welcome to the program, Corrado Passera. When you look at Italy, there was a lot of anxiousness out there in the market over the summer. Do you think now investors concerned have been delayed (ph) because actually this government, like any Italian government, needs the markets?

PASSERA: Absolutely. And anxiety was justified because of some of the announcements that were made in the first weeks after the creation of the government. But even today, the statements or the announcements that Tria made were the right ones because he talked about growth and growth through investment, increased the investment both public and private, that's the key word in my opinion, and he said very clearly, we will stick to our commitment in terms of debt reduction. So growth, investment, commitments on debt is the combination of things that markets expect. Then we will look at the stability now in the details but these three main announcements are good ones.

LACQUA: Is there a discount to Italian banks because of the political situation? You're actually starting a challenger bank. It's a niche bank that actually tries to lend to SME.

PASSERA: Challenger and niche are two concepts that probably do not convey the right message because niche means small and it's not the kind of --

LACQUA: So for now, that's all.

PASSERA: The bank is small but the market is really booming and then (inaudible) need for financing with SMEs is very big. On the other side, challenger gives the right the message but we want to be -- we will be a special event. I mean, we want to do only a number things, three asset lines with SMEs that are very interesting, profitable and useful project for the country. And we will do it in a totally new paradigm way. So it's -- at the end, it's a challenge to others. But in a number of ways, we will also collaborate with the incumbents because we will buy guilty (ph) piece unlikely to pay, we will buy NPLs, we will manage to help second tier SMEs that have potential to grow, so it's more than that.

LACQUA: Okay. You didn't answer my question on Italian banks. I'll come to you in a second.

PASSERA: Yes. No, you're right.

LACQUA: But actually, Nouriel, what's your take overall on Italian banks and the Italian GDP? Should we worry about it, so like Mr. (inaudible) tells us or should markets remain cool about it?

ROUBINI: Well, there is some positive about Italy is that the market constraints in E.U. are going to force them to keep the budget deficit for the next year around the current level as a share of GDP. That's the positive. And euro membership is not on the table, so they have been controlled and contained by market discipline. However, spread in Italian debt are still 250 basis points, first of all, the economy is slowing down very sharply. And even if they want to maintain the deficit at around 2% of GDP, it's going to be problematic because they want to spend more and cut taxes by 1%, they don't know how they're going to finance it, they might fudge it by making estimates about growth for next year too high, 1.6, when market estimates are more like 0.8. And many of their policies are leading to a reduction of potential growth rather than an increase of potential growth, reverse in the reform of pension, restricting the labor market flexibility and so on and so on. So actual growth is falling, potential growth is falling, real rates are high or even before the ECB has ended up QE and the loosening of the primary balance implies that it's going to be very hard for them to stabilize the debt ratio and reduce it. It might go higher. And therefore, Italy is still on a knife edge situation from an economic point of view. And there is still political risk. Salvini is popular. And after the budget, the law is passed, it might go to election, that's going to create more uncertainty. So in the short run, I don't think that the spreads are going to widen, things are going to stabilize given their fiscal commitment, but Italy is facing a number of economic, fiscal and financial challenges over the next couple of years.

KEENE: Nouriel, I want to explain this distinction. Mariana Mazzucato and Kenneth Rogoff sat right where you're sitting five or six days ago. And sometimes the body language -- and Jason, bring it in here, the body language we see on camera, like if I'm like this, I'm like really board and then you sit up straight and listen. Ken Rogoff sat up straight when the topic was Italy. Why is a guy like Ken Rogoff totally focused on Italy?

ROUBINI: Well, it's not just Ken Rogoff, it's also the markets. When -- a couple of weeks ago, Salvini and Di Maio said, we're going to increase the deficit from two to three. The spread suddenly overnight went from 250 to over 300 and they flip-flopped in 24 hours. And they sided then to say, no, we're going to stick to the E.U. rules.

KEENE: (Inaudible) is that the heritage of Italy is that the adjacency of Italy on the Bloomberg screen, it's a G7 country. Why the focus on Italy?

ROUBINI: Well, Italy has now become, for the first time, a country run by populists, Italian debt is 135% of GDP and is the largest debt in absolute terms after U.S. and Japan in the world economy. Greece could be built out by (inaudible) program was, after all, only needs EURO200 billion public debt problem, Italy is 2.3 trillion public debt problem. So Italy is too big to fail but also too big to be saved. There is no (inaudible) program, they could backstop Italy if Italy goes in the wrong direction. Therefore, Italy is systemic for Italy for Eurozone, if Italy were to leave, there will be a systemic shock to the Eurozone and then it could be a threat to the global economy. That's why people are interested in Italy.

KEENE: Francine?

LACQUA: Right. Yes. And, Nouriel, I would go a step further and saying this is not an obsession on Italy, it's also an obsession with Italian banks. If there's a problem with Italian banks, do the markets actually discount them and forget sometimes all of the work that's done on non-performing loans over the last three years?

PASSERA: Nouriel is right in listing the risks and banks obviously are short of proxy over the old countries. So if all the wrong things are done, that we will have troubles. But I don't expect all the wrong things will be done. We all know that the so-called government contract, the two coalition parties have agreed upon -- it's not feasible and it will be implemented, in my opinion, only partially and only gradually. Having said that, banks, banks have gone through at least three main crisis, the financial asset crisis reasonably well managed, the credit asset crisis and we are digesting, we are getting out of it. I mean, NPLs and UTPs are still an important component of our asset balance sheets but they are being deluded. We had a number of single bank crisis, some of them very, very bad ones, but they're now sold, partially paid by the tax payers but are now gone. And now, we are going through the more structural transformation, reshaping of the industry, because digital technologies regulation, the entrance by big tech companies in the credit world and monetary policies are making the traditional business models very unsustainable. But new winners are coming in that area.

LACQUA: Okay. But do we need a banking consolidation in Italy? It's almost difficult to deny that actually Italy is not overbanked?

PASSERA: No, it's not overbanked but --

LACQUA: But it's not overbanked.

PASSERA: It's not overbanked in a sense that we will have a new mix of players in the next years. Small and medium-sized banks are too generic and too traditional to sustain the competition will get out of the market for sure, and some of them to consolidation. Some of the big ones will keep investing in innovation and they will be players. Some entrance from other industries will be players. But we will certainly -- we can expect a number of specialty players, new paradigm kind of players in terms of business system to enter the market. And so market will change a lot. In terms of consolidation, Italy has been one of the countries that have consolidated the most. I mean, take, for example, Germany, I mean, much more than Germany. And now with the law that has been passed on Popolare and Rural (inaudible) cooperative banks, 300 of them will become free. So at the end, we will be landing (ph) around 100, that the steel is a large number. But compared with the 1,800 banks in Germany, I mean, it shows that we have done a good part of the road ahead.

LACQUA: Nouriel, do you think we'll see a banking union in our lifetime and will that help with consolidation?

ROUBINI: Well, I fear that for time being, there is not going to be a full banking union in the Eurozone, even a proposal for a common deposit insurance scheme in the Eurozone has been pushed back by Germany. Germany fears that risk sharing is re-shifting and a fiscal union effectively becomes like a transfer union. And given now there are political uncertainties in Italy, Germany is pushing back even the (inaudible) the proposals of Macron have not been accepted. They push them from June to December, then there'll be E.U. parliamentary election. And therefore, any agenda about finalizing the banking union and increasing the element of risk sharing is not going to happen until Germany and other parts of the north (ph) are going to have more security about what's happening in Italy and the periphery Eurozone.

KEENE: Nouriel, let's continue here. Nouriel Roubini with us in New York. And we thank Corrado Passera in Milan.

It is one thing to talk about immigrants for we are all immigrants, there is actually the generational doing of it. One person that knows this call (ph) is Nouriel Roubini of Roubini Macro Associates and, of course, New York University, one of the world's acclaimed international economist. And now, he'll speak with where he started out, Istanbul in Turkey. How long were you in Istanbul for, a cup of coffee?

ROUBINI: Well, I was born there. And this time, I was there for about a week. I went to Istanbul, I went to Ankara, I saw the news on policymakers and so on. So -- and I was there right at that time when the currency was plunging from (inaudible).

KEENE: Is it traditional economics? Is it Irving Fisher economics where, right now, the currency links right in the interest rates links, right into inflation and shows potential dampened GDP and frankly crisis?

ROUBINI: Yes, there is a severe risk of a balance of payment in crisis over a sudden stop of capital, the huge amount of dollar that especially in the banking system, that corporate sector. And, of course, going from three to five to seven, I was around 6.3, implies a massive negative balance sheet affects on the corporate and the financial sector. That's why actually the currency is not leading the fall of the currency to an economic stimulus. If anything, the economy now is going into a recession. The latest economic data suggested that Turkey is going to have a credit crunch, it's going to enter a recession by probably the third quarter of this year. So you have the impact of the currency depreciation with dollar debt is contractioning rather than being expansionary, it leads to higher inflation. It forces the central bank to hike rates, finally, they have shown some independence. But monetary tightening is not sufficient because you have massive fiscal -- cause a fiscal and credit stimulus in the economy that led to overheating for him to win the election, and therefore, now they have to tighten also credit fiscal and quasi fiscal policy. But they have a regional election next March. And therefore, they want to avoid the recession because they want to win those important local elections, and therefore, they're not tightening the fiscal and credit range as much as they should.

LACQUA: Right. So, Nouriel, what will it take to put Turkey on a more stable footing? It seems that the central bank actually did a lot and yet investors aren't convinced?

ROUBINI: Well, in Argentina the policy red (ph) were pushed to 60% with inflation slightly above the one of Turkey. In Turkey, finally, they pushed them from 17% towards 24%. That's a positive especially because the signal to the central bank is now slightly more independent even if Erdogan, the president, keeps on attacking the central banks and the interest will lobby (ph). But as I pointed out, you have massive imbalances both internal on the fiscal side and the savings and the spending of the private sector and external with very large current account deficit. Therefore, you need monetary tightening, probably more because inflation is going to rise, fiscal tightening and credit tightening. What that implies, you have to accept a recession. The (inaudible) is already going into a recession by the time where politically his support is deriving by having strong economic growth and you have an election coming next spring. So I don't think they're going to be doing enough because if they're doing enough, they're going to plunge the economy into a recession, that this point is unavoidable. And therefore, the weakening of the currency is going to continue to occur even after this monetary tightening, and we've seen it in the last couple of days. So the currency is weakening (inaudible), and there are political uncertainties as well. So they're not doing enough. Argentina, what that means is promising enough and the currency has still weakened. Turkey is not even promising to do what's necessary.

LACQUA: So how do you find the floor in Turkish lira? Do you assume that it just continues falling until a politically -- I guess, the ruling class accepts that they could go into a recession?

ROUBINI: Yes. First of all, inflation is going to go higher given the currency of the depreciation, so even 24% rate is not enough. They'll have to tighten more as inflation goes higher. And as I say, the main imbalances are not just on the monetary side but fiscal for the fiscal and credit, and that slowdown has not occurred. They have promised a fiscal tightening, it has not occurred. And politically, for them, accepting a recession is going to be very painful and they're going to try to kick the can down the road at least until March of next year, until after those elections. Given that situation, I think the currency can weaken in nominal and real term even if it has fallen significantly. It can fall more if inflation gets higher. So I don't see yet the bottom for the Turkish lira.

KEENE: Okay. Nouriel, I want to talk about this right now because a lot of people say, what's the big deal with Nouriel Roubini? Here's why Nouriel Roubini is famous, going back to 2005 and 2007, we'll drive it forward. This is a fancy physics question which is sinusoidal function, a sign way (ph) function. And what Nouriel Roubini is famous for is his A right here, which is the amplitude of a given wave. And, Nouriel, this goes back to 2006, which was the amplitude of the crisis that everybody underestimated. Is that where we are right now where we really don't understand the amplitudes of Turkey, the amplitudes of Argentina or frankly the amplitudes that could have come out of this trade year?

ROUBINI: Yes, we don't know it because we don't know what the policy responses are going to be in Turkey and Argentina. Therefore, the market, given the uncertainty, they tend to overreact and there're overshooting of prices. In a case of the trade war, that was 50, then 200, now, they are saying, 267, and that's not going to be just rates. Their technology for a large investment could be a global trade war, it could be a de-globalization.

KEENE: Because of time, Nouriel, it's a critical question, and do you overlay a new kind of shadow banking where we all underestimate the A in that equation, the amplitude of a potential shock. (Inaudible) the shadow banking right now?

ROUBINI: Well, the shadow banking in China is in serious trouble. They tried to rein it in but (inaudible) shadow banking in the global financial system. People say the banks now have more liquidity, less leverage and more capital, yes. But a lot of financial transactions have gone in the shadow banking system globally, that have been rising. Leverage has been rising. And therefore, we're always fighting the last war. The last war was the banks were the problem. This time around, it might be the rest of the capital markets, it could be the shadow banking system certainly in China but even in the United States. You have algo trading, you have all these credit funds that are open-ended and are illiquid, you have a variety of things like the market makers are not there, they're not warehousing, the broker-dealers are not doing those activities. Those are sources of illiquidity and amplification of economic and financial shock over time.

KEENE: And not only, Nouriel, that but the dollarization which maybe we'll have time to get. Nouriel Roubini with us, Roubini Macro Associates, Tom Keene in New York, Francine Lacqua in Milan, for your briefing coast to coast and indeed worldwide.

Let's do that with a brilliant essay, Rosa & Roubini writing in project syndicate. The space for fiscal stimulus is already limited by a massive public debt. Mr. Kudlow didn't want to talk about that yesterday. Unlike in 2008, when governments had the policy tools needed to prevent a free fall, the policymakers who much confront the next downturn will have their hands tied while overall debt levels are higher than during the previous crisis. This is a surprising essay, Nouriel Roubini. Why will the policymakers have their hands tied? I thought regulators were doing a great job.

ROUBINI: Well, on fiscal policy, we're running now another $2 trillion fiscal deficit over the next ten years. So when the likes of a recession comes, higher deficit, and that implies we don't have room to do stimulus. The fed is not going to have much headroom even if we reach to 75 before the next recession. Typically, you have 500, 600 basis points. So they're going to go to zero, forward guidance is not going to be enough. And doing quantitative is easing is going to be more difficult. And then the political willingness to backstop the banks our corporates are not going to be there. There's a populist backlash and many countries in the world are at insolvent (ph) governments, so they can't even bail out their own firms even if they want to. So all the policy tools are going to be much more constrained next time around in a world in which overall debt levels are higher.

KEENE: Of these menu of items, the one that is immediate is yesterday, Mr. Kudlow made very clear that he believes that you can grow your way out of a deficit. He cited not once but twice in his conversation at the Economic Club of New York that they've already modeled out new Trumpian growth that will bring in taxes to pay the deficit. I know you don't buy that. I didn't think the audience bought as well. Push against the idea that you can grow your way out of a deficit. What does history tell us?

ROUBINI: Well, it's good economics. Reagan tried it, Bush tried it. And this time around, look at the latest number. The deficit since last year has already, in August, doubled. And it's going to double because you have to $2 trillion budget deficit. Next year, we're going to have a budget deficit that is going to be overall $1 trillion. The deficit (inaudible) to the public $1 trillion per year for them as far as the eye can see. So it's totally good economics. Of course, it cut taxes, there is some short room in growth but they're going to be minimal, the the CBO (ph) estimates over a decade 0.1% increase in GDP level, okay. That is nothing as close to zero. Then a fiscal drag to the effect on long-term, short rates in the dollar, there will be a crowding out of that growth. And to contain it, then they have to increase rapidly taxes on the household sectors starting in 2024. So there will be a massive drag starting then but there will be already fiscal drag in 2020. The economy is going now three rather than two because this year and next year, there's a fiscal stimulus. By 2020, that still becomes a small fiscal drag. So not only are we going to go from three to two, we're going to go below two, we're going to go towards 1.8. So it's an artificial fiscal stimulus, unsustainable, peace time, first time ever, during and after a recession, and it's going to crowd out economic growth overtime.

LACQUA: What does that mean for yields, Nouriel, treasury yields?

ROUBINI: Well, overtime, the combination of the U.S. monetary policy and the fed tightening and this fiscal stimulus implies that long-term interest rates have gone higher and they're going to keep on going higher. Now, what keeps the lead right now on long-term trades in the U.S. is that while the fed controls the short end of the yield curve, ECB, BOJ and other central banks are controlling the long-term of the yield curve because there is still unconventional policies in other parts of the world. But guess what, the ECB decided we're going to finish QE and then start normalizing rate next year. Other central banks in Europe are going to do the same thing. Therefore, global liquidity is going to start to shrink. And therefore, once that happens, and you still have the stimulus, U.S. long-term interest rates are going to tend to go higher, (inaudible) is going higher, the dollar is going to strengthen, the current account deficit is going to become higher, and therefore, the crowding by late next year of that economic recovery into a fiscal drag in 2020 into a tightening by the fed towards 3.5%. And they have to go towards 3.5% because the fiscal stimulus leads to an overheating of the economy. And that tighter fiscal policy and tighter monetary policy could plunge the economy into a stall by 2020 if you add the trade frictions, the capital market frictions. In fact, there'll be a slowdown in emerging market, in Europe, in China, and, in fact, that asset prices, as you know, are frothy. Profit and P ratios are 50% higher than the historical average. So when the markets see the slowdown occurring to 2020, there will be market correction and that's going to have a negative world effect. So you might have by 2020 a perfect storm for the U.S. and the global economy.

LACQUA: Okay. Will the central bank have enough tools to deal with this perfect storm if we were to have it by 2020?

ROUBINI: I think there are differences this time around, is that we are having policies that are stagflationary that reduce growth but also increase inflation. For the last decade, all the shocks were stagflationary, meaning lower growth and lower inflation, and therefore, central banks were doing even more in doubling down on more unconventional policies. But if you're going to have trade restriction, if you are going to have a restriction to capital flows, you're going to have a restriction to FDI and technology transfers, if you're going to have a restriction migration, if you're not going to invest into renewable resources, if you're not going to invest into renewable resources, if you're not going to invest into infrastructure and there's no plan. All those shocks are stagflationary, are going to release (ph) growth, are going to force inflation higher. And when that happens when the economy is overheating, that's going to force the fed to hike more faster and sooner rather than ease (ph), as it happens whenever you've had a policy shock that they have been stagflationary, like the oil (ph) shock, '73, '79, '99. Because if you don't tighten, inflation expectation go higher and then you're in the worst situation. So the type of policy that is going to be followed by the U.S. are going to imply force and effect to have to tighten rather than ease, even if growth slows down, because inflation and inflation expectations are going to go to higher. That's a difference in the ability and willingness of the fed and other central to react to that economic slowdown. It's driven by negative supply side shocks.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much for all of the insights. Nouriel Roubini there of Roubini Macro Associates, he stays with us.

KEENE: Right now, let's look at something we've avoided with Nouriel Roubini this morning, we're going to do it, we're going to dive in for a quick comment. Copper looks lousy. Right now, Dr. Roubini, Dr. Copper, this is just a textbook depressed commodity chart (inaudible) teach in one of your sessions in NYU, Nouriel. This should be a lead chart. What does it signal that we're seeing this dampening in something like copper?

ROUBINI: Well, it signals that there is a potential slowdown in the global economy signal.

KEENE: You take it right over to GDP?

ROUBINI: Yes. Emerging markets are slowing down, China will have to slowdown, and whether there's a correlation between the value of the dollar and the dollar prices of commodities, when the dollar is stronger, the dollar price of commodity tends to fall. So I would say, the weakening in copper is an ominous signal. And I would say also the increase in oil prices is an ominous signal because it's like a negative supply side shock to the global economy and that drives in the oil prices, it's not driven by demand growth but it's driven by the fact that the sanction on Iran right now are equivalent to a supply side shock, like it's happening in the previous episode. So that's even is a negative. Usually higher oil prices implies strong global growth. In this case, it's driven by a supply shock rather than (inaudible) shock so it's a negative for global growth.

KEENE: This has been wonderful and congratulations on your essay with Mr. Rosa in Project Syndicate. I'll get that out on social, folks. I really recommend that. It's a thought-provoking view forward looking back to the Lehman crisis. Nouriel Roubini, of course, with Roubini Macro Associates as well.

END
