urn:contentItem:5T9G-CSG1-DY0W-415S-00000-00Nouriel Roubini, Corrado Passera are interviewed on BB TV2018-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:30ZLexisNexisNouriel Roubini, Corrado Passera are interviewed on BB TVWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: And there is no one better to do that with Nouriel Roubini of New York University. Professor Roubini as acclaimed getting upfront of the crisis of 2007, I personally did that with him in Davos at one point in '05 or '06. And I'm thrilled to have Nouriel here on this important day. Let bring up from Enda Curran in Hong Kong a chart which is great because it's hard to read. I really mean that. It's hard to read this chart. Bring it up right now on radio. It is a massive disproportion of U.S. imports of China's stuff versus what they take from us. Here we are with the tariffs here, the tariffs there and China is just tiny, tiny, tiny. Professor Roubini, this is the arch-imbalance of President Trump's certitude. I heard this from Lawrence Kudlow yesterday at the economic club of New York. They speak of us as equals in trade dynamics or not, are we?

NOURIEL ROUBINI, CHAIRMAN & PROFESSOR, ROUBINI MACRO ASSOCIATES NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: We're not equal in terms of trade dynamics but has many other ways to retaliate. Of course, they've only 130 billion of imports from the U.S. while the U.S. imports from China more than 500 billion. But let's not forget that the U.S. firms, whether Apple, Gem (ph), hundreds of others, have done hundreds of billions of dollars of foreign direct investment in China. In the past, when China (inaudible) with Japan or Korea, they took action against these foreign investments, and therefore, they can retaliate and they're going to start doing it in many different ways. China can also retaliate by letting its currency weaken. Renminbi has already fallen at 8%. And then there's the nuclear option of dumping U.S. treasury, and I don't think that's likely. So the idea that there's an imbalance and China cannot retaliate, I think, is actually the wrong argument.

KEENE: Your heritage of being born in Istanbul, have studied in Milan, studied with Jeff Sax at Harvard, your international sense, your old world sense, is a study of how China will react. Jonathan Spence 101 at Yale University, how would you presume that China will react to this approach by Mr. Trump?

ROUBINI: First of all, the Chinese can be flexible. They need to do reforms and some of the reforms (inaudible) upper hand. But China and President Xi Jinping cannot lose face (ph). And what happens is that United States is starting not just a trade war with China but geopolitically wants to contain China. China is never giving up on its own Made in China 2025 program, for example. And therefore, the risk is that if you try to contain China, China is going to become actually more aggressive and less cooperative. And I think that's what's going to likely happen. They're going to retaliate in many different ways. So this is going to be counterproductive.

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: (Inaudible) from Milan, do we underestimate the dangers of a Chinese GDP that is slowing down or even does the size of shadow banking in China?

ROUBINI: Well, there has been a slowdown in China. But every time there is excessive slowdown after a tightening of monetary, fiscal and credit policy, there is an easing of monetary, credit, fiscal policy. China has not ran out of tools, yet there has been a significant correction of the stock market, 25% but the world effect is small. Yes, default rates have gone up because they are reducing leverage and align more flexibility. But that's manageable. And the currency weakening actually is occurring right now and their capital controls has not (inaudible) in 2015 and '16. And that actually helps China. If their currency goes down by 8%, the U.S. imposes tariffs on 10% is a bit of a wash in terms of their competitiveness. So China has the macroeconomic policy tools to manage its own slowdown. Of course, China, so far, has kicked the can down the road and not dealing with too much and too fast enough with the issues of overcapacity, overleverage and debt, but China is going to do it gradually. And China is going to take the long-term view. China is going to be in a long-term competition with the United States once Mao was allegedly asked what he thought of the French Revolution, he said, too early to tell. And China takes an approach a decade longer. We have midterm election, we have election ever two years, China has no elections, so they can take control on their own policies and face and threaten the U.S. over the medium and long-term. So they may win this war.

LACQUA: Right. But, Nouriel, I guess what I'm trying to get at is they do have the tools to manage a slowdown. But if they only focus domestically on what they need to do, do they let the emerging markets down and what does that mean for markets overall?

ROUBINI: Well, of course, the emerging markets are hurting right now for a number of global factors. China is one of them. The risk of trade war is one of them, either directly or through China. But then U.S. fed policies and fiscal policy, (inaudible), higher, longer and short rates, stronger dollar, and a stronger dollar means a lower dollar price of commodity. So these are the global factors that all EM are facing. But China were to react to the risk of a trade war by boosting domestic demand and maintaining its own economic growth closer to their 6.5% target, and recently, actually, they're growing faster in 6.5%, then that's going to be a backstop for emerging markets. So, of course, if China were to go to a hard landing, then that's going to hurt emerging markets, but also the U.S., Europe and the world economy. But in my view, China have still some of the policy tools to manage that economic slowdown.

KEENE: I saw Ambassador Hormats yesterday, Robert Hormats, he was an assistant of Secretary Clinton. And there is someone with a certain set of views. And I think of someone he works for, Dr. Kissinger, or Robert Kaplan, who has my book of the summer, writing about China and the Pacific Rim. All of that is a neo-realist view. What's the neo-realist response to a president who wants to put on layers of taxes called tariffs?

ROUBINI: Well, the Chinese know that, effectively, by imposing these tariffs on China, they'll increase the cost of lots of goods up to $500 billion that used by U.S. consumers. And the fact that, for example, they may introduce for September 10 and push it 25% on January 1st, is they don't want to have a (inaudible) shock for consumers during the holiday as well.

KEENE: Right. I don't mean to interrupt you but this is critical. This is Roubini 101 at Stern School New York University. Are we able to say that within all this mumbo-jumbo, a tariff is a tax on an American consumer? Is that a safe statement?

ROUBINI: Yes, it's absolutely true. Whenever you impose tariffs, you're increasing the price on imports certainly for consumer products but also for a variety of other intermediate products and the fact also the business sector. But this first (inaudible) is a tax. And by the way, it's a very regressive tax because those kinds of consumer goods that we buy from China are usually bought at Walmart and other types of firms and they're bought by lower income individuals. So not only the tax but it's an extremely regressive tax.

KEENE: And this is important, Francine, with you in Milan. I mean, the bottom line here is this is not a tax on Gucci, is it?

LACQUA: Well, let me ask Nouriel. Away from Gucci, is this a tax that could actually plunge the U.S. into a recession in the next 18 months?

ROUBINI: No. I don't think that that alone is going to plunge the U.S. into a recession, even if my prediction that a variety of other factors can push the U.S. into a recession by 2020, monetary policy, fiscal policy, the trade war, other frictions, what's happening with the rest of the world, but certainly I think that people underestimate the impact of this trade war on the economy because they say the trade impacts directly, indirectly, are too small to matter. That's not true because, first of all, you have retaliation. And as long as you have retaliation, the impact is bigger. Secondly is that tax on consumer that uses disposable income, it's going to slowdown consumption. Three, it's going to affect both business and consumer confidence. In addition, it's going to push down, emerging markets are going to hurt them, it's going to push down the price of commodity. And finally, they're going to have an effect only also on investor's confidence. If the stock market in China has gone down 20% this year under the threat of trade wars, in fact, later in the summer, the U.S. market was going down as well. So there's going to be a generalized trade war, not 50 billion, but it's going to be 500 billion and there's going to be a retaliation, there's going to be other things, there's going to be a bigger impact. And right now, this is not just a trade war. The U.S. is going to impose restriction on inward FDI (ph) into the U.S. by China to outward FDI (ph) by United States firms, they want to have all U.S. firms getting out of China, they're going to have global supply chains, technology transfer and so on and so on. So this is not just about trading goods. It's about technology, it's about IP, it's about FDI (ph), inward and outward, and you're going to roll, this is going to become de-globalized, it's going to become Volckanized, in which these frictions are going to have a negative stagflationary impact of reducing growth and increasing inflation globally. That's the danger of this trade war.

LACQUA: All right. Well, that gets us started certainly. Nouriel Roubini there of Roubini Macro Associates stays with us.

Well I'm pleased to be joined by Corrado Passera. He is SPAXS' Chief Executive Officer and Founder, former Italian Minister of Economic Development and, for almost a decade, the Chief Executive of one of Italy's biggest bank. Still with us in New York, Nouriel Roubini of Roubini Macro Associates. So thank you for sticking around, Nouriel. Welcome to the program, Corrado Passera. When you look at Italy, there was a lot of anxiousness out there in the market over the summer. Do you think now investors concerned have been delayed (ph) because actually this government, like any Italian government, needs the markets?

CORRADO PASSERA, CEO & FOUNDER, SPAXS: Absolutely. And anxiety was justified because of some of the announcements that were made in the first weeks after the creation of the government. But even today, the statements or the announcements that Tria made were the right ones because he talked about growth and growth through investment, increased the investment both public and private, that's the key word in my opinion, and he said very clearly, we will stick to our commitment in terms of debt reduction. So growth, investment, commitments on debt is the combination of things that markets expect. Then we will look at the stability now in the details but these three main announcements are good ones.

LACQUA: Is there a discount to Italian banks because of the political situation? You're actually starting a challenger bank. It's a niche bank that actually tries to lend to SME.

PASSERA: Challenger and niche are two concepts that probably do not convey the right message because niche means small and it's not the kind of --

LACQUA: So for now, that's all.

PASSERA: The bank is small but the market is really booming and then (inaudible) need for financing with SMEs is very big. On the other side, challenger gives the right the message but we want to be -- we will be a special event. I mean, we want to do only a number things, three asset lines with SMEs that are very interesting, profitable and useful project for the country. And we will do it in a totally new paradigm way. So it's - - at the end, it's a challenge to others. But in a number of ways, we will also collaborate with the incumbents because we will buy guilty (ph) piece unlikely to pay, we will buy NPLs, we will manage to help second tier SMEs that have potential to grow, so it's more than that.

LACQUA: Okay. You didn't answer my question on Italian banks. I'll come to you in a second.

PASSERA: Yes. No, you're right.

LACQUA: But actually, Nouriel, what's your take overall on Italian banks and the Italian GDP? Should we worry about it, so like Mr. (inaudible) tells us or should markets remain cool about it?

ROUBINI: Well, there is some positive about Italy is that the market constraints in E.U. are going to force them to keep the budget deficit for the next year around the current level as a share of GDP. That's the positive. And euro membership is not on the table, so they have been controlled and contained by market discipline. However, spread in Italian debt are still 250 basis points, first of all, the economy is slowing down very sharply. And even if they want to maintain the deficit at around 2% of GDP, it's going to be problematic because they want to spend more and cut taxes by 1%, they don't know how they're going to finance it, they might fudge it by making estimates about growth for next year too high, 1.6, when market estimates are more like 0.8. And many of their policies are leading to a reduction of potential growth rather than an increase of potential growth, reverse in the reform of pension, restricting the labor market flexibility and so on and so on. So actual growth is falling, potential growth is falling, real rates are high or even before the ECB has ended up QE and the loosening of the primary balance implies that it's going to be very hard for them to stabilize the debt ratio and reduce it. It might go higher. And therefore, Italy is still on a knife edge situation from an economic point of view. And there is still political risk. Salvini is popular. And after the budget, the law is passed, it might go to election, that's going to create more uncertainty. So in the short run, I don't think that the spreads are going to widen, things are going to stabilize given their fiscal commitment, but Italy is facing a number of economic, fiscal and financial challenges over the next couple of years.

KEENE: Nouriel, I want to explain this distinction. Mariana Mazzucato and Kenneth Rogoff sat right where you're sitting five or six days ago. And sometimes the body language -- and Jason, bring it in here, the body language we see on camera, like if I'm like this, I'm like really board and then you sit up straight and listen. Ken Rogoff sat up straight when the topic was Italy. Why is a guy like Ken Rogoff totally focused on Italy?

ROUBINI: Well, it's not just Ken Rogoff, it's also the markets. When -- a couple of weeks ago, Salvini and Di Maio said, we're going to increase the deficit from two to three. The spread suddenly overnight went from 250 to over 300 and they flip-flopped in 24 hours. And they sided then to say, no, we're going to stick to the E.U. rules.

KEENE: (Inaudible) is that the heritage of Italy is that the adjacency of Italy on the Bloomberg screen, it's a G7 country. Why the focus on Italy?

ROUBINI: Well, Italy has now become, for the first time, a country run by populists, Italian debt is 135% of GDP and is the largest debt in absolute terms after U.S. and Japan in the world economy. Greece could be built out by (inaudible) program was, after all, only needs _200 billion public debt problem, Italy is 2.3 trillion public debt problem. So Italy is too big to fail but also too big to be saved. There is no (inaudible) program, they could backstop Italy if Italy goes in the wrong direction. Therefore, Italy is systemic for Italy for Eurozone, if Italy were to leave, there will be a systemic shock to the Eurozone and then it could be a threat to the global economy. That's why people are interested in Italy.

KEENE: Francine?

LACQUA: Right. Yes. And, Nouriel, I would go a step further and saying this is not an obsession on Italy, it's also an obsession with Italian banks. If there's a problem with Italian banks, do the markets actually discount them and forget sometimes all of the work that's done on non-performing loans over the last three years?

PASSERA: Nouriel is right in listing the risks and banks obviously are short of proxy over the old countries. So if all the wrong things are done, that we will have troubles. But I don't expect all the wrong things will be done. We all know that the so-called government contract, the two coalition parties have agreed upon -- it's not feasible and it will be implemented, in my opinion, only partially and only gradually. Having said that, banks, banks have gone through at least three main crisis, the financial asset crisis reasonably well managed, the credit asset crisis and we are digesting, we are getting out of it. I mean, NPLs and UTPs are still an important component of our asset balance sheets but they are being deluded. We had a number of single bank crisis, some of them very, very bad ones, but they're now sold, partially paid by the tax payers but are now gone. And now, we are going through the more structural transformation, reshaping of the industry, because digital technologies regulation, the entrance by big tech companies in the credit world and monetary policies are making the traditional business models very unsustainable. But new winners are coming in that area.

LACQUA: Okay. But do we need a banking consolidation in Italy? It's almost difficult to deny that actually Italy is not overbanked?

PASSERA: No, it's not overbanked but --

LACQUA: But it's not overbanked.

PASSERA: It's not overbanked in a sense that we will have a new mix of players in the next years. Small and medium-sized banks are too generic and too traditional to sustain the competition will get out of the market for sure, and some of them to consolidation. Some of the big ones will keep investing in innovation and they will be players. Some entrance from other industries will be players. But we will certainly -- we can expect a number of specialty players, new paradigm kind of players in terms of business system to enter the market. And so market will change a lot. In terms of consolidation, Italy has been one of the countries that have consolidated the most. I mean, take, for example, Germany, I mean, much more than Germany. And now with the law that has been passed on Popolare and Rural (inaudible) cooperative banks, 300 of them will become free. So at the end, we will be landing (ph) around 100, that the steel is a large number. But compared with the 1,800 banks in Germany, I mean, it shows that we have done a good part of the road ahead.

LACQUA: Nouriel, do you think we'll see a banking union in our lifetime and will that help with consolidation?

ROUBINI: Well, I fear that for time being, there is not going to be a full banking union in the Eurozone, even a proposal for a common deposit insurance scheme in the Eurozone has been pushed back by Germany. Germany fears that risk sharing is re-shifting and a fiscal union effectively becomes like a transfer union. And given now there are political uncertainties in Italy, Germany is pushing back even the (inaudible) the proposals of Macron have not been accepted. They push them from June to December, then there'll be E.U. parliamentary election. And therefore, any agenda about finalizing the banking union and increasing the element of risk sharing is not going to happen until Germany and other parts of the north (ph) are going to have more security about what's happening in Italy and the periphery Eurozone.

KEENE: Nouriel, let's continue here. Nouriel Roubini with us in New York. And we thank Corrado Passera in Milan.

It is one thing to talk about immigrants for we are all immigrants, there is actually the generational doing of it. One person that knows this call (ph) is Nouriel Roubini of Roubini Macro Associates and, of course, New York University, one of the world's acclaimed international economist. And now, he'll speak with where he started out, Istanbul in Turkey. How long were you in Istanbul for, a cup of coffee?

ROUBINI: Well, I was born there. And this time, I was there for about a week. I went to Istanbul, I went to Ankara, I saw the news on policymakers and so on. So -- and I was there right at that time when the currency was plunging from (inaudible).

KEENE: Is it traditional economics? Is it Irving Fisher economics where, right now, the currency links right in the interest rates links, right into inflation and shows potential dampened GDP and frankly crisis?

ROUBINI: Yes, there is a severe risk of a balance of payment in crisis over a sudden stop of capital, the huge amount of dollar that especially in the banking system, that corporate sector. And, of course, going from three to five to seven, I was around 6.3, implies a massive negative balance sheet affects on the corporate and the financial sector. That's why actually the currency is not leading the fall of the currency to an economic stimulus. If anything, the economy now is going into a recession. The latest economic data suggested that Turkey is going to have a credit crunch, it's going to enter a recession by probably the third quarter of this year. So you have the impact of the currency depreciation with dollar debt is contractioning rather than being expansionary, it leads to higher inflation. It forces the central bank to hike rates, finally, they have shown some independence. But monetary tightening is not sufficient because you have massive fiscal -- cause a fiscal and credit stimulus in the economy that led to overheating for him to win the election, and therefore, now they have to tighten also credit fiscal and quasi fiscal policy. But they have a regional election next March. And therefore, they want to avoid the recession because they want to win those important local elections, and therefore, they're not tightening the fiscal and credit range as much as they should.

LACQUA: Right. So, Nouriel, what will it take to put Turkey on a more stable footing? It seems that the central bank actually did a lot and yet investors aren't convinced?

ROUBINI: Well, in Argentina the policy red (ph) were pushed to 60% with inflation slightly above the one of Turkey. In Turkey, finally, they pushed them from 17% towards 24%. That's a positive especially because the signal to the central bank is now slightly more independent even if Erdogan, the president, keeps on attacking the central banks and the interest will lobby (ph). But as I pointed out, you have massive imbalances both internal on the fiscal side and the savings and the spending of the private sector and external with very large current account deficit. Therefore, you need monetary tightening, probably more because inflation is going to rise, fiscal tightening and credit tightening. What that implies, you have to accept a recession. The (inaudible) is already going into a recession by the time where politically his support is deriving by having strong economic growth and you have an election coming next spring. So I don't think they're going to be doing enough because if they're doing enough, they're going to plunge the economy into a recession, that this point is unavoidable. And therefore, the weakening of the currency is going to continue to occur even after this monetary tightening, and we've seen it in the last couple of days. So the currency is weakening (inaudible), and there are political uncertainties as well. So they're not doing enough. Argentina, what that means is promising enough and the currency has still weakened. Turkey is not even promising to do what's necessary.

LACQUA: So how do you find the floor in Turkish lira? Do you assume that it just continues falling until a politically -- I guess, the ruling class accepts that they could go into a recession?

ROUBINI: Yes. First of all, inflation is going to go higher given the currency of the depreciation, so even 24% rate is not enough. They'll have to tighten more as inflation goes higher. And as I say, the main imbalances are not just on the monetary side but fiscal for the fiscal and credit, and that slowdown has not occurred. They have promised a fiscal tightening, it has not occurred. And politically, for them, accepting a recession is going to be very painful and they're going to try to kick the can down the road at least until March of next year, until after those elections. Given that situation, I think the currency can weaken in nominal and real term even if it has fallen significantly. It can fall more if inflation gets higher. So I don't see yet the bottom for the Turkish lira.

KEENE: Okay. Nouriel, I want to talk about this right now because a lot of people say, what's the big deal with Nouriel Roubini? Here's why Nouriel Roubini is famous, going back to 2005 and 2007, we'll drive it forward. This is a fancy physics question which is sinusoidal function, a sign way (ph) function. And what Nouriel Roubini is famous for is his A right here, which is the amplitude of a given wave. And, Nouriel, this goes back to 2006, which was the amplitude of the crisis that everybody underestimated. Is that where we are right now where we really don't understand the amplitudes of Turkey, the amplitudes of Argentina or frankly the amplitudes that could have come out of this trade year?

ROUBINI: Yes, we don't know it because we don't know what the policy responses are going to be in Turkey and Argentina. Therefore, the market, given the uncertainty, they tend to overreact and there're overshooting of prices. In a case of the trade war, that was 50, then 200, now, they are saying, 267, and that's not going to be just rates. Their technology for a large investment could be a global trade war, it could be a de- globalization.

KEENE: Because of time, Nouriel, it's a critical question, and do you overlay a new kind of shadow banking where we all underestimate the A in that equation, the amplitude of a potential shock. (Inaudible) the shadow banking right now?

ROUBINI: Well, the shadow banking in China is in serious trouble. They tried to rein it in but (inaudible) shadow banking in the global financial system. People say the banks now have more liquidity, less leverage and more capital, yes. But a lot of financial transactions have gone in the shadow banking system globally, that have been rising. Leverage has been rising. And therefore, we're always fighting the last war. The last war was the banks were the problem. This time around, it might be the rest of the capital markets, it could be the shadow banking system certainly in China but even in the United States. You have algo trading, you have all these credit funds that are open-ended and are illiquid, you have a variety of things like the market makers are not there, they're not warehousing, the broker-dealers are not doing those activities. Those are sources of illiquidity and amplification of economic and financial shock over time.

KEENE: And not only, Nouriel, that but the dollarization which maybe we'll have time to get. Nouriel Roubini with us, Roubini Macro Associates, Tom Keene in New York, Francine Lacqua in Milan, for your briefing coast to coast and indeed worldwide.

Let's do that with a brilliant essay, Rosa & Roubini writing in project syndicate. The space for fiscal stimulus is already limited by a massive public debt. Mr. Kudlow didn't want to talk about that yesterday. Unlike in 2008, when governments had the policy tools needed to prevent a free fall, the policymakers who much confront the next downturn will have their hands tied while overall debt levels are higher than during the previous crisis. This is a surprising essay, Nouriel Roubini. Why will the policymakers have their hands tied? I thought regulators were doing a great job.

ROUBINI: Well, on fiscal policy, we're running now another $2 trillion fiscal deficit over the next ten years. So when the likes of a recession comes, higher deficit, and that implies we don't have room to do stimulus. The fed is not going to have much headroom even if we reach to 75 before the next recession. Typically, you have 500, 600 basis points. So they're going to go to zero, forward guidance is not going to be enough. And doing quantitative is easing is going to be more difficult. And then the political willingness to backstop the banks our corporates are not going to be there. There's a populist backlash and many countries in the world are at insolvent (ph) governments, so they can't even bail out their own firms even if they want to. So all the policy tools are going to be much more constrained next time around in a world in which overall debt levels are higher.

KEENE: Of these menu of items, the one that is immediate is yesterday, Mr. Kudlow made very clear that he believes that you can grow your way out of a deficit. He cited not once but twice in his conversation at the Economic Club of New York that they've already modeled out new Trumpian growth that will bring in taxes to pay the deficit. I know you don't buy that. I didn't think the audience bought as well. Push against the idea that you can grow your way out of a deficit. What does history tell us?

ROUBINI: Well, it's good economics. Reagan tried it, Bush tried it. And this time around, look at the latest number. The deficit since last year has already, in August, doubled. And it's going to double because you have to $2 trillion budget deficit. Next year, we're going to have a budget deficit that is going to be overall $1 trillion. The deficit (inaudible) to the public $1 trillion per year for them as far as the eye can see. So it's totally good economics. Of course, it cut taxes, there is some short room in growth but they're going to be minimal, the the CBO (ph) estimates over a decade 0.1% increase in GDP level, okay. That is nothing as close to zero. Then a fiscal drag to the effect on long-term, short rates in the dollar, there will be a crowding out of that growth. And to contain it, then they have to increase rapidly taxes on the household sectors starting in 2024. So there will be a massive drag starting then but there will be already fiscal drag in 2020. The economy is going now three rather than two because this year and next year, there's a fiscal stimulus. By 2020, that still becomes a small fiscal drag. So not only are we going to go from three to two, we're going to go below two, we're going to go towards 1.8. So it's an artificial fiscal stimulus, unsustainable, peace time, first time ever, during and after a recession, and it's going to crowd out economic growth overtime.

LACQUA: What does that mean for yields, Nouriel, treasury yields?

ROUBINI: Well, overtime, the combination of the U.S. monetary policy and the fed tightening and this fiscal stimulus implies that long-term interest rates have gone higher and they're going to keep on going higher. Now, what keeps the lead right now on long-term trades in the U.S. is that while the fed controls the short end of the yield curve, ECB, BOJ and other central banks are controlling the long-term of the yield curve because there is still unconventional policies in other parts of the world. But guess what, the ECB decided we're going to finish QE and then start normalizing rate next year. Other central banks in Europe are going to do the same thing. Therefore, global liquidity is going to start to shrink. And therefore, once that happens, and you still have the stimulus, U.S. long-term interest rates are going to tend to go higher, (inaudible) is going higher, the dollar is going to strengthen, the current account deficit is going to become higher, and therefore, the crowding by late next year of that economic recovery into a fiscal drag in 2020 into a tightening by the fed towards 3.5%. And they have to go towards 3.5% because the fiscal stimulus leads to an overheating of the economy. And that tighter fiscal policy and tighter monetary policy could plunge the economy into a stall by 2020 if you add the trade frictions, the capital market frictions. In fact, there'll be a slowdown in emerging market, in Europe, in China, and, in fact, that asset prices, as you know, are frothy. Profit and P ratios are 50% higher than the historical average. So when the markets see the slowdown occurring to 2020, there will be market correction and that's going to have a negative world effect. So you might have by 2020 a perfect storm for the U.S. and the global economy.

LACQUA: Okay. Will the central bank have enough tools to deal with this perfect storm if we were to have it by 2020?

ROUBINI: I think there are differences this time around, is that we are having policies that are stagflationary that reduce growth but also increase inflation. For the last decade, all the shocks were stagflationary, meaning lower growth and lower inflation, and therefore, central banks were doing even more in doubling down on more unconventional policies. But if you're going to have trade restriction, if you are going to have a restriction to capital flows, you're going to have a restriction to FDI and technology transfers, if you're going to have a restriction migration, if you're not going to invest into renewable resources, if you're not going to invest into renewable resources, if you're not going to invest into infrastructure and there's no plan. All those shocks are stagflationary, are going to release (ph) growth, are going to force inflation higher. And when that happens when the economy is overheating, that's going to force the fed to hike more faster and sooner rather than ease (ph), as it happens whenever you've had a policy shock that they have been stagflationary, like the oil (ph) shock, '73, '79, '99. Because if you don't tighten, inflation expectation go higher and then you're in the worst situation. So the type of policy that is going to be followed by the U.S. are going to imply force and effect to have to tighten rather than ease, even if growth slows down, because inflation and inflation expectations are going to go to higher. That's a difference in the ability and willingness of the fed and other central to react to that economic slowdown. It's driven by negative supply side shocks.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much for all of the insights. Nouriel Roubini there of Roubini Macro Associates, he stays with us.

KEENE: Right now, let's look at something we've avoided with Nouriel Roubini this morning, we're going to do it, we're going to dive in for a quick comment. Copper looks lousy. Right now, Dr. Roubini, Dr. Copper, this is just a textbook depressed commodity chart (inaudible) teach in one of your sessions in NYU, Nouriel. This should be a lead chart. What does it signal that we're seeing this dampening in something like copper?

ROUBINI: Well, it signals that there is a potential slowdown in the global economy signal.

KEENE: You take it right over to GDP?

ROUBINI: Yes. Emerging markets are slowing down, China will have to slowdown, and whether there's a correlation between the value of the dollar and the dollar prices of commodities, when the dollar is stronger, the dollar price of commodity tends to fall. So I would say, the weakening in copper is an ominous signal. And I would say also the increase in oil prices is an ominous signal because it's like a negative supply side shock to the global economy and that drives in the oil prices, it's not driven by demand growth but it's driven by the fact that the sanction on Iran right now are equivalent to a supply side shock, like it's happening in the previous episode. So that's even is a negative. Usually higher oil prices implies strong global growth. In this case, it's driven by a supply shock rather than (inaudible) shock so it's a negative for global growth.

KEENE: This has been wonderful and congratulations on your essay with Mr. Rosa in Project Syndicate. I'll get that out on social, folks. I really recommend that. It's a thought-provoking view forward looking back to the Lehman crisis. Nouriel Roubini, of course, with Roubini Macro Associates as well.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: And there is no one better to do that with Nouriel Roubini of New York University. Professor Roubini as acclaimed getting upfront of the crisis of 2007, I personally did that with him in Davos at one point in '05 or '06. And I'm thrilled to have Nouriel here on this important day. Let bring up from Enda Curran in Hong Kong a chart which is great because it's hard to read. I really mean that. It's hard to read this chart. Bring it up right now on radio. It is a massive disproportion of U.S. imports of China's stuff versus what they take from us. Here we are with the tariffs here, the tariffs there and China is just tiny, tiny, tiny. Professor Roubini, this is the arch-imbalance of President Trump's certitude. I heard this from Lawrence Kudlow yesterday at the economic club of New York. They speak of us as equals in trade dynamics or not, are we?

NOURIEL ROUBINI, CHAIRMAN & PROFESSOR, ROUBINI MACRO ASSOCIATES NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: We're not equal in terms of trade dynamics but has many other ways to retaliate. Of course, they've only 130 billion of imports from the U.S. while the U.S. imports from China more than 500 billion. But let's not forget that the U.S. firms, whether Apple, Gem (ph), hundreds of others, have done hundreds of billions of dollars of foreign direct investment in China. In the past, when China (inaudible) with Japan or Korea, they took action against these foreign investments, and therefore, they can retaliate and they're going to start doing it in many different ways. China can also retaliate by letting its currency weaken. Renminbi has already fallen at 8%. And then there's the nuclear option of dumping U.S. treasury, and I don't think that's likely. So the idea that there's an imbalance and China cannot retaliate, I think, is actually the wrong argument.

KEENE: Your heritage of being born in Istanbul, have studied in Milan, studied with Jeff Sax at Harvard, your international sense, your old world sense, is a study of how China will react. Jonathan Spence 101 at Yale University, how would you presume that China will react to this approach by Mr. Trump?

ROUBINI: First of all, the Chinese can be flexible. They need to do reforms and some of the reforms (inaudible) upper hand. But China and President Xi Jinping cannot lose face (ph). And what happens is that United States is starting not just a trade war with China but geopolitically wants to contain China. China is never giving up on its own Made in China 2025 program, for example. And therefore, the risk is that if you try to contain China, China is going to become actually more aggressive and less cooperative. And I think that's what's going to likely happen. They're going to retaliate in many different ways. So this is going to be counterproductive.

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: (Inaudible) from Milan, do we underestimate the dangers of a Chinese GDP that is slowing down or even does the size of shadow banking in China?

ROUBINI: Well, there has been a slowdown in China. But every time there is excessive slowdown after a tightening of monetary, fiscal and credit policy, there is an easing of monetary, credit, fiscal policy. China has not ran out of tools, yet there has been a significant correction of the stock market, 25% but the world effect is small. Yes, default rates have gone up because they are reducing leverage and align more flexibility. But that's manageable. And the currency weakening actually is occurring right now and their capital controls has not (inaudible) in 2015 and '16. And that actually helps China. If their currency goes down by 8%, the U.S. imposes tariffs on 10% is a bit of a wash in terms of their competitiveness. So China has the macroeconomic policy tools to manage its own slowdown. Of course, China, so far, has kicked the can down the road and not dealing with too much and too fast enough with the issues of overcapacity, overleverage and debt, but China is going to do it gradually. And China is going to take the long-term view. China is going to be in a long-term competition with the United States once Mao was allegedly asked what he thought of the French Revolution, he said, too early to tell. And China takes an approach a decade longer. We have midterm election, we have election ever two years, China has no elections, so they can take control on their own policies and face and threaten the U.S. over the medium and long-term. So they may win this war.

LACQUA: Right. But, Nouriel, I guess what I'm trying to get at is they do have the tools to manage a slowdown. But if they only focus domestically on what they need to do, do they let the emerging markets down and what does that mean for markets overall?

ROUBINI: Well, of course, the emerging markets are hurting right now for a number of global factors. China is one of them. The risk of trade war is one of them, either directly or through China. But then U.S. fed policies and fiscal policy, (inaudible), higher, longer and short rates, stronger dollar, and a stronger dollar means a lower dollar price of commodity. So these are the global factors that all EM are facing. But China were to react to the risk of a trade war by boosting domestic demand and maintaining its own economic growth closer to their 6.5% target, and recently, actually, they're growing faster in 6.5%, then that's going to be a backstop for emerging markets. So, of course, if China were to go to a hard landing, then that's going to hurt emerging markets, but also the U.S., Europe and the world economy. But in my view, China have still some of the policy tools to manage that economic slowdown.

KEENE: I saw Ambassador Hormats yesterday, Robert Hormats, he was an assistant of Secretary Clinton. And there is someone with a certain set of views. And I think of someone he works for, Dr. Kissinger, or Robert Kaplan, who has my book of the summer, writing about China and the Pacific Rim. All of that is a neo-realist view. What's the neo-realist response to a president who wants to put on layers of taxes called tariffs?

ROUBINI: Well, the Chinese know that, effectively, by imposing these tariffs on China, they'll increase the cost of lots of goods up to $500 billion that used by U.S. consumers. And the fact that, for example, they may introduce for September 10 and push it 25% on January 1st, is they don't want to have a (inaudible) shock for consumers during the holiday as well.

KEENE: Right. I don't mean to interrupt you but this is critical. This is Roubini 101 at Stern School New York University. Are we able to say that within all this mumbo-jumbo, a tariff is a tax on an American consumer? Is that a safe statement?

ROUBINI: Yes, it's absolutely true. Whenever you impose tariffs, you're increasing the price on imports certainly for consumer products but also for a variety of other intermediate products and the fact also the business sector. But this first (inaudible) is a tax. And by the way, it's a very regressive tax because those kinds of consumer goods that we buy from China are usually bought at Walmart and other types of firms and they're bought by lower income individuals. So not only the tax but it's an extremely regressive tax.

KEENE: And this is important, Francine, with you in Milan. I mean, the bottom line here is this is not a tax on Gucci, is it?

LACQUA: Well, let me ask Nouriel. Away from Gucci, is this a tax that could actually plunge the U.S. into a recession in the next 18 months?

ROUBINI: No. I don't think that that alone is going to plunge the U.S. into a recession, even if my prediction that a variety of other factors can push the U.S. into a recession by 2020, monetary policy, fiscal policy, the trade war, other frictions, what's happening with the rest of the world, but certainly I think that people underestimate the impact of this trade war on the economy because they say the trade impacts directly, indirectly, are too small to matter. That's not true because, first of all, you have retaliation. And as long as you have retaliation, the impact is bigger. Secondly is that tax on consumer that uses disposable income, it's going to slowdown consumption. Three, it's going to affect both business and consumer confidence. In addition, it's going to push down, emerging markets are going to hurt them, it's going to push down the price of commodity. And finally, they're going to have an effect only also on investor's confidence. If the stock market in China has gone down 20% this year under the threat of trade wars, in fact, later in the summer, the U.S. market was going down as well. So there's going to be a generalized trade war, not 50 billion, but it's going to be 500 billion and there's going to be a retaliation, there's going to be other things, there's going to be a bigger impact. And right now, this is not just a trade war. The U.S. is going to impose restriction on inward FDI (ph) into the U.S. by China to outward FDI (ph) by United States firms, they want to have all U.S. firms getting out of China, they're going to have global supply chains, technology transfer and so on and so on. So this is not just about trading goods. It's about technology, it's about IP, it's about FDI (ph), inward and outward, and you're going to roll, this is going to become de-globalized, it's going to become Volckanized, in which these frictions are going to have a negative stagflationary impact of reducing growth and increasing inflation globally. That's the danger of this trade war.

LACQUA: All right. Well, that gets us started certainly. Nouriel Roubini there of Roubini Macro Associates stays with us.

Well I'm pleased to be joined by Corrado Passera. He is SPAXS' Chief Executive Officer and Founder, former Italian Minister of Economic Development and, for almost a decade, the Chief Executive of one of Italy's biggest bank. Still with us in New York, Nouriel Roubini of Roubini Macro Associates. So thank you for sticking around, Nouriel. Welcome to the program, Corrado Passera. When you look at Italy, there was a lot of anxiousness out there in the market over the summer. Do you think now investors concerned have been delayed (ph) because actually this government, like any Italian government, needs the markets?

CORRADO PASSERA, CEO & FOUNDER, SPAXS: Absolutely. And anxiety was justified because of some of the announcements that were made in the first weeks after the creation of the government. But even today, the statements or the announcements that Tria made were the right ones because he talked about growth and growth through investment, increased the investment both public and private, that's the key word in my opinion, and he said very clearly, we will stick to our commitment in terms of debt reduction. So growth, investment, commitments on debt is the combination of things that markets expect. Then we will look at the stability now in the details but these three main announcements are good ones.

LACQUA: Is there a discount to Italian banks because of the political situation? You're actually starting a challenger bank. It's a niche bank that actually tries to lend to SME.

PASSERA: Challenger and niche are two concepts that probably do not convey the right message because niche means small and it's not the kind of --

LACQUA: So for now, that's all.

PASSERA: The bank is small but the market is really booming and then (inaudible) need for financing with SMEs is very big. On the other side, challenger gives the right the message but we want to be -- we will be a special event. I mean, we want to do only a number things, three asset lines with SMEs that are very interesting, profitable and useful project for the country. And we will do it in a totally new paradigm way. So it's - - at the end, it's a challenge to others. But in a number of ways, we will also collaborate with the incumbents because we will buy guilty (ph) piece unlikely to pay, we will buy NPLs, we will manage to help second tier SMEs that have potential to grow, so it's more than that.

LACQUA: Okay. You didn't answer my question on Italian banks. I'll come to you in a second.

PASSERA: Yes. No, you're right.

LACQUA: But actually, Nouriel, what's your take overall on Italian banks and the Italian GDP? Should we worry about it, so like Mr. (inaudible) tells us or should markets remain cool about it?

ROUBINI: Well, there is some positive about Italy is that the market constraints in E.U. are going to force them to keep the budget deficit for the next year around the current level as a share of GDP. That's the positive. And euro membership is not on the table, so they have been controlled and contained by market discipline. However, spread in Italian debt are still 250 basis points, first of all, the economy is slowing down very sharply. And even if they want to maintain the deficit at around 2% of GDP, it's going to be problematic because they want to spend more and cut taxes by 1%, they don't know how they're going to finance it, they might fudge it by making estimates about growth for next year too high, 1.6, when market estimates are more like 0.8. And many of their policies are leading to a reduction of potential growth rather than an increase of potential growth, reverse in the reform of pension, restricting the labor market flexibility and so on and so on. So actual growth is falling, potential growth is falling, real rates are high or even before the ECB has ended up QE and the loosening of the primary balance implies that it's going to be very hard for them to stabilize the debt ratio and reduce it. It might go higher. And therefore, Italy is still on a knife edge situation from an economic point of view. And there is still political risk. Salvini is popular. And after the budget, the law is passed, it might go to election, that's going to create more uncertainty. So in the short run, I don't think that the spreads are going to widen, things are going to stabilize given their fiscal commitment, but Italy is facing a number of economic, fiscal and financial challenges over the next couple of years.

KEENE: Nouriel, I want to explain this distinction. Mariana Mazzucato and Kenneth Rogoff sat right where you're sitting five or six days ago. And sometimes the body language -- and Jason, bring it in here, the body language we see on camera, like if I'm like this, I'm like really board and then you sit up straight and listen. Ken Rogoff sat up straight when the topic was Italy. Why is a guy like Ken Rogoff totally focused on Italy?

ROUBINI: Well, it's not just Ken Rogoff, it's also the markets. When -- a couple of weeks ago, Salvini and Di Maio said, we're going to increase the deficit from two to three. The spread suddenly overnight went from 250 to over 300 and they flip-flopped in 24 hours. And they sided then to say, no, we're going to stick to the E.U. rules.

KEENE: (Inaudible) is that the heritage of Italy is that the adjacency of Italy on the Bloomberg screen, it's a G7 country. Why the focus on Italy?

ROUBINI: Well, Italy has now become, for the first time, a country run by populists, Italian debt is 135% of GDP and is the largest debt in absolute terms after U.S. and Japan in the world economy. Greece could be built out by (inaudible) program was, after all, only needs _200 billion public debt problem, Italy is 2.3 trillion public debt problem. So Italy is too big to fail but also too big to be saved. There is no (inaudible) program, they could backstop Italy if Italy goes in the wrong direction. Therefore, Italy is systemic for Italy for Eurozone, if Italy were to leave, there will be a systemic shock to the Eurozone and then it could be a threat to the global economy. That's why people are interested in Italy.

KEENE: Francine?

LACQUA: Right. Yes. And, Nouriel, I would go a step further and saying this is not an obsession on Italy, it's also an obsession with Italian banks. If there's a problem with Italian banks, do the markets actually discount them and forget sometimes all of the work that's done on non-performing loans over the last three years?

PASSERA: Nouriel is right in listing the risks and banks obviously are short of proxy over the old countries. So if all the wrong things are done, that we will have troubles. But I don't expect all the wrong things will be done. We all know that the so-called government contract, the two coalition parties have agreed upon -- it's not feasible and it will be implemented, in my opinion, only partially and only gradually. Having said that, banks, banks have gone through at least three main crisis, the financial asset crisis reasonably well managed, the credit asset crisis and we are digesting, we are getting out of it. I mean, NPLs and UTPs are still an important component of our asset balance sheets but they are being deluded. We had a number of single bank crisis, some of them very, very bad ones, but they're now sold, partially paid by the tax payers but are now gone. And now, we are going through the more structural transformation, reshaping of the industry, because digital technologies regulation, the entrance by big tech companies in the credit world and monetary policies are making the traditional business models very unsustainable. But new winners are coming in that area.

LACQUA: Okay. But do we need a banking consolidation in Italy? It's almost difficult to deny that actually Italy is not overbanked?

PASSERA: No, it's not overbanked but --

LACQUA: But it's not overbanked.

PASSERA: It's not overbanked in a sense that we will have a new mix of players in the next years. Small and medium-sized banks are too generic and too traditional to sustain the competition will get out of the market for sure, and some of them to consolidation. Some of the big ones will keep investing in innovation and they will be players. Some entrance from other industries will be players. But we will certainly -- we can expect a number of specialty players, new paradigm kind of players in terms of business system to enter the market. And so market will change a lot. In terms of consolidation, Italy has been one of the countries that have consolidated the most. I mean, take, for example, Germany, I mean, much more than Germany. And now with the law that has been passed on Popolare and Rural (inaudible) cooperative banks, 300 of them will become free. So at the end, we will be landing (ph) around 100, that the steel is a large number. But compared with the 1,800 banks in Germany, I mean, it shows that we have done a good part of the road ahead.

LACQUA: Nouriel, do you think we'll see a banking union in our lifetime and will that help with consolidation?

ROUBINI: Well, I fear that for time being, there is not going to be a full banking union in the Eurozone, even a proposal for a common deposit insurance scheme in the Eurozone has been pushed back by Germany. Germany fears that risk sharing is re-shifting and a fiscal union effectively becomes like a transfer union. And given now there are political uncertainties in Italy, Germany is pushing back even the (inaudible) the proposals of Macron have not been accepted. They push them from June to December, then there'll be E.U. parliamentary election. And therefore, any agenda about finalizing the banking union and increasing the element of risk sharing is not going to happen until Germany and other parts of the north (ph) are going to have more security about what's happening in Italy and the periphery Eurozone.

KEENE: Nouriel, let's continue here. Nouriel Roubini with us in New York. And we thank Corrado Passera in Milan.

It is one thing to talk about immigrants for we are all immigrants, there is actually the generational doing of it. One person that knows this call (ph) is Nouriel Roubini of Roubini Macro Associates and, of course, New York University, one of the world's acclaimed international economist. And now, he'll speak with where he started out, Istanbul in Turkey. How long were you in Istanbul for, a cup of coffee?

ROUBINI: Well, I was born there. And this time, I was there for about a week. I went to Istanbul, I went to Ankara, I saw the news on policymakers and so on. So -- and I was there right at that time when the currency was plunging from (inaudible).

KEENE: Is it traditional economics? Is it Irving Fisher economics where, right now, the currency links right in the interest rates links, right into inflation and shows potential dampened GDP and frankly crisis?

ROUBINI: Yes, there is a severe risk of a balance of payment in crisis over a sudden stop of capital, the huge amount of dollar that especially in the banking system, that corporate sector. And, of course, going from three to five to seven, I was around 6.3, implies a massive negative balance sheet affects on the corporate and the financial sector. That's why actually the currency is not leading the fall of the currency to an economic stimulus. If anything, the economy now is going into a recession. The latest economic data suggested that Turkey is going to have a credit crunch, it's going to enter a recession by probably the third quarter of this year. So you have the impact of the currency depreciation with dollar debt is contractioning rather than being expansionary, it leads to higher inflation. It forces the central bank to hike rates, finally, they have shown some independence. But monetary tightening is not sufficient because you have massive fiscal -- cause a fiscal and credit stimulus in the economy that led to overheating for him to win the election, and therefore, now they have to tighten also credit fiscal and quasi fiscal policy. But they have a regional election next March. And therefore, they want to avoid the recession because they want to win those important local elections, and therefore, they're not tightening the fiscal and credit range as much as they should.

LACQUA: Right. So, Nouriel, what will it take to put Turkey on a more stable footing? It seems that the central bank actually did a lot and yet investors aren't convinced?

ROUBINI: Well, in Argentina the policy red (ph) were pushed to 60% with inflation slightly above the one of Turkey. In Turkey, finally, they pushed them from 17% towards 24%. That's a positive especially because the signal to the central bank is now slightly more independent even if Erdogan, the president, keeps on attacking the central banks and the interest will lobby (ph). But as I pointed out, you have massive imbalances both internal on the fiscal side and the savings and the spending of the private sector and external with very large current account deficit. Therefore, you need monetary tightening, probably more because inflation is going to rise, fiscal tightening and credit tightening. What that implies, you have to accept a recession. The (inaudible) is already going into a recession by the time where politically his support is deriving by having strong economic growth and you have an election coming next spring. So I don't think they're going to be doing enough because if they're doing enough, they're going to plunge the economy into a recession, that this point is unavoidable. And therefore, the weakening of the currency is going to continue to occur even after this monetary tightening, and we've seen it in the last couple of days. So the currency is weakening (inaudible), and there are political uncertainties as well. So they're not doing enough. Argentina, what that means is promising enough and the currency has still weakened. Turkey is not even promising to do what's necessary.

LACQUA: So how do you find the floor in Turkish lira? Do you assume that it just continues falling until a politically -- I guess, the ruling class accepts that they could go into a recession?

ROUBINI: Yes. First of all, inflation is going to go higher given the currency of the depreciation, so even 24% rate is not enough. They'll have to tighten more as inflation goes higher. And as I say, the main imbalances are not just on the monetary side but fiscal for the fiscal and credit, and that slowdown has not occurred. They have promised a fiscal tightening, it has not occurred. And politically, for them, accepting a recession is going to be very painful and they're going to try to kick the can down the road at least until March of next year, until after those elections. Given that situation, I think the currency can weaken in nominal and real term even if it has fallen significantly. It can fall more if inflation gets higher. So I don't see yet the bottom for the Turkish lira.

KEENE: Okay. Nouriel, I want to talk about this right now because a lot of people say, what's the big deal with Nouriel Roubini? Here's why Nouriel Roubini is famous, going back to 2005 and 2007, we'll drive it forward. This is a fancy physics question which is sinusoidal function, a sign way (ph) function. And what Nouriel Roubini is famous for is his A right here, which is the amplitude of a given wave. And, Nouriel, this goes back to 2006, which was the amplitude of the crisis that everybody underestimated. Is that where we are right now where we really don't understand the amplitudes of Turkey, the amplitudes of Argentina or frankly the amplitudes that could have come out of this trade year?

ROUBINI: Yes, we don't know it because we don't know what the policy responses are going to be in Turkey and Argentina. Therefore, the market, given the uncertainty, they tend to overreact and there're overshooting of prices. In a case of the trade war, that was 50, then 200, now, they are saying, 267, and that's not going to be just rates. Their technology for a large investment could be a global trade war, it could be a de- globalization.

KEENE: Because of time, Nouriel, it's a critical question, and do you overlay a new kind of shadow banking where we all underestimate the A in that equation, the amplitude of a potential shock. (Inaudible) the shadow banking right now?

ROUBINI: Well, the shadow banking in China is in serious trouble. They tried to rein it in but (inaudible) shadow banking in the global financial system. People say the banks now have more liquidity, less leverage and more capital, yes. But a lot of financial transactions have gone in the shadow banking system globally, that have been rising. Leverage has been rising. And therefore, we're always fighting the last war. The last war was the banks were the problem. This time around, it might be the rest of the capital markets, it could be the shadow banking system certainly in China but even in the United States. You have algo trading, you have all these credit funds that are open-ended and are illiquid, you have a variety of things like the market makers are not there, they're not warehousing, the broker-dealers are not doing those activities. Those are sources of illiquidity and amplification of economic and financial shock over time.

KEENE: And not only, Nouriel, that but the dollarization which maybe we'll have time to get. Nouriel Roubini with us, Roubini Macro Associates, Tom Keene in New York, Francine Lacqua in Milan, for your briefing coast to coast and indeed worldwide.

Let's do that with a brilliant essay, Rosa & Roubini writing in project syndicate. The space for fiscal stimulus is already limited by a massive public debt. Mr. Kudlow didn't want to talk about that yesterday. Unlike in 2008, when governments had the policy tools needed to prevent a free fall, the policymakers who much confront the next downturn will have their hands tied while overall debt levels are higher than during the previous crisis. This is a surprising essay, Nouriel Roubini. Why will the policymakers have their hands tied? I thought regulators were doing a great job.

ROUBINI: Well, on fiscal policy, we're running now another $2 trillion fiscal deficit over the next ten years. So when the likes of a recession comes, higher deficit, and that implies we don't have room to do stimulus. The fed is not going to have much headroom even if we reach to 75 before the next recession. Typically, you have 500, 600 basis points. So they're going to go to zero, forward guidance is not going to be enough. And doing quantitative is easing is going to be more difficult. And then the political willingness to backstop the banks our corporates are not going to be there. There's a populist backlash and many countries in the world are at insolvent (ph) governments, so they can't even bail out their own firms even if they want to. So all the policy tools are going to be much more constrained next time around in a world in which overall debt levels are higher.

KEENE: Of these menu of items, the one that is immediate is yesterday, Mr. Kudlow made very clear that he believes that you can grow your way out of a deficit. He cited not once but twice in his conversation at the Economic Club of New York that they've already modeled out new Trumpian growth that will bring in taxes to pay the deficit. I know you don't buy that. I didn't think the audience bought as well. Push against the idea that you can grow your way out of a deficit. What does history tell us?

ROUBINI: Well, it's good economics. Reagan tried it, Bush tried it. And this time around, look at the latest number. The deficit since last year has already, in August, doubled. And it's going to double because you have to $2 trillion budget deficit. Next year, we're going to have a budget deficit that is going to be overall $1 trillion. The deficit (inaudible) to the public $1 trillion per year for them as far as the eye can see. So it's totally good economics. Of course, it cut taxes, there is some short room in growth but they're going to be minimal, the the CBO (ph) estimates over a decade 0.1% increase in GDP level, okay. That is nothing as close to zero. Then a fiscal drag to the effect on long-term, short rates in the dollar, there will be a crowding out of that growth. And to contain it, then they have to increase rapidly taxes on the household sectors starting in 2024. So there will be a massive drag starting then but there will be already fiscal drag in 2020. The economy is going now three rather than two because this year and next year, there's a fiscal stimulus. By 2020, that still becomes a small fiscal drag. So not only are we going to go from three to two, we're going to go below two, we're going to go towards 1.8. So it's an artificial fiscal stimulus, unsustainable, peace time, first time ever, during and after a recession, and it's going to crowd out economic growth overtime.

LACQUA: What does that mean for yields, Nouriel, treasury yields?

ROUBINI: Well, overtime, the combination of the U.S. monetary policy and the fed tightening and this fiscal stimulus implies that long-term interest rates have gone higher and they're going to keep on going higher. Now, what keeps the lead right now on long-term trades in the U.S. is that while the fed controls the short end of the yield curve, ECB, BOJ and other central banks are controlling the long-term of the yield curve because there is still unconventional policies in other parts of the world. But guess what, the ECB decided we're going to finish QE and then start normalizing rate next year. Other central banks in Europe are going to do the same thing. Therefore, global liquidity is going to start to shrink. And therefore, once that happens, and you still have the stimulus, U.S. long-term interest rates are going to tend to go higher, (inaudible) is going higher, the dollar is going to strengthen, the current account deficit is going to become higher, and therefore, the crowding by late next year of that economic recovery into a fiscal drag in 2020 into a tightening by the fed towards 3.5%. And they have to go towards 3.5% because the fiscal stimulus leads to an overheating of the economy. And that tighter fiscal policy and tighter monetary policy could plunge the economy into a stall by 2020 if you add the trade frictions, the capital market frictions. In fact, there'll be a slowdown in emerging market, in Europe, in China, and, in fact, that asset prices, as you know, are frothy. Profit and P ratios are 50% higher than the historical average. So when the markets see the slowdown occurring to 2020, there will be market correction and that's going to have a negative world effect. So you might have by 2020 a perfect storm for the U.S. and the global economy.

LACQUA: Okay. Will the central bank have enough tools to deal with this perfect storm if we were to have it by 2020?

ROUBINI: I think there are differences this time around, is that we are having policies that are stagflationary that reduce growth but also increase inflation. For the last decade, all the shocks were stagflationary, meaning lower growth and lower inflation, and therefore, central banks were doing even more in doubling down on more unconventional policies. But if you're going to have trade restriction, if you are going to have a restriction to capital flows, you're going to have a restriction to FDI and technology transfers, if you're going to have a restriction migration, if you're not going to invest into renewable resources, if you're not going to invest into renewable resources, if you're not going to invest into infrastructure and there's no plan. All those shocks are stagflationary, are going to release (ph) growth, are going to force inflation higher. And when that happens when the economy is overheating, that's going to force the fed to hike more faster and sooner rather than ease (ph), as it happens whenever you've had a policy shock that they have been stagflationary, like the oil (ph) shock, '73, '79, '99. Because if you don't tighten, inflation expectation go higher and then you're in the worst situation. So the type of policy that is going to be followed by the U.S. are going to imply force and effect to have to tighten rather than ease, even if growth slows down, because inflation and inflation expectations are going to go to higher. That's a difference in the ability and willingness of the fed and other central to react to that economic slowdown. It's driven by negative supply side shocks.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much for all of the insights. Nouriel Roubini there of Roubini Macro Associates, he stays with us.

KEENE: Right now, let's look at something we've avoided with Nouriel Roubini this morning, we're going to do it, we're going to dive in for a quick comment. Copper looks lousy. Right now, Dr. Roubini, Dr. Copper, this is just a textbook depressed commodity chart (inaudible) teach in one of your sessions in NYU, Nouriel. This should be a lead chart. What does it signal that we're seeing this dampening in something like copper?

ROUBINI: Well, it signals that there is a potential slowdown in the global economy signal.

KEENE: You take it right over to GDP?

ROUBINI: Yes. Emerging markets are slowing down, China will have to slowdown, and whether there's a correlation between the value of the dollar and the dollar prices of commodities, when the dollar is stronger, the dollar price of commodity tends to fall. So I would say, the weakening in copper is an ominous signal. And I would say also the increase in oil prices is an ominous signal because it's like a negative supply side shock to the global economy and that drives in the oil prices, it's not driven by demand growth but it's driven by the fact that the sanction on Iran right now are equivalent to a supply side shock, like it's happening in the previous episode. So that's even is a negative. Usually higher oil prices implies strong global growth. In this case, it's driven by a supply shock rather than (inaudible) shock so it's a negative for global growth.

KEENE: This has been wonderful and congratulations on your essay with Mr. Rosa in Project Syndicate. I'll get that out on social, folks. I really recommend that. It's a thought-provoking view forward looking back to the Lehman crisis. Nouriel Roubini, of course, with Roubini Macro Associates as well.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Nouriel Roubini, Corrado Passera discuss economics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: And there is no one better to do that with Nouriel Roubini of New York University. Professor Roubini as acclaimed getting upfront of the crisis of 2007, I personally did that with him in Davos at one point in '05 or '06. And I'm thrilled to have Nouriel here on this important day. Let bring up from Enda Curran in Hong Kong a chart which is great because it's hard to read. I really mean that. It's hard to read this chart. Bring it up right now on radio. It is a massive disproportion of U.S. imports of China's stuff versus what they take from us. Here we are with the tariffs here, the tariffs there and China is just tiny, tiny, tiny. Professor Roubini, this is the arch-imbalance of President Trump's certitude. I heard this from Lawrence Kudlow yesterday at the economic club of New York. They speak of us as equals in trade dynamics or not, are we?

NOURIEL ROUBINI, CHAIRMAN & PROFESSOR, ROUBINI MACRO ASSOCIATES NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: We're not equal in terms of trade dynamics but has many other ways to retaliate. Of course, they've only 130 billion of imports from the U.S. while the U.S. imports from China more than 500 billion. But let's not forget that the U.S. firms, whether Apple, Gem (ph), hundreds of others, have done hundreds of billions of dollars of foreign direct investment in China. In the past, when China (inaudible) with Japan or Korea, they took action against these foreign investments, and therefore, they can retaliate and they're going to start doing it in many different ways. China can also retaliate by letting its currency weaken. Renminbi has already fallen at 8%. And then there's the nuclear option of dumping U.S. treasury, and I don't think that's likely. So the idea that there's an imbalance and China cannot retaliate, I think, is actually the wrong argument.

So I would say, the weakening in copper is an ominous signal. And I would say also the increase in oil prices is an ominous signal because it's like a negative supply side shock to the global economy and that drives in the oil prices, it's not driven by demand growth but it's driven by the fact that the sanction on Iran right now are equivalent to a supply side shock, like it's happening in the previous episode. So that's even is a negative. Usually higher oil prices implies strong global growth. In this case, it's driven by a supply shock rather than (inaudible) shock so it's a negative for global growth.

KEENE: This has been wonderful and congratulations on your essay with Mr. Rosa in Project Syndicate. I'll get that out on social, folks. I really recommend that. It's a thought-provoking view forward looking back to the Lehman crisis. Nouriel Roubini, of course, with Roubini Macro Associates as well.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
